“Git up! What you ’bout?”
I opened my eyes and looked around, trying to make out where I was. It was after sun-up, and I had been sound asleep. Pap was standing over me looking sour and sick, too. He says:
“What you doin’ with this gun?”
I judged he didn’t know nothing about what he had been doing, so I says:
“Somebody tried to get in, so I was laying for him.”
“Why didn’t you roust me out?”
“Well, I tried to, but I couldn’t; I couldn’t budge you.”
“Well, all right. Don’t stand there palavering all day, but out with you and see if there’s a fish on the lines for breakfast. I’ll be along in a minute.”
He unlocked the door, and I cleared out up the river-bank. I noticed some pieces of limbs and such things floating down, and a sprinkling of bark; so I knowed the river had begun to rise. I reckoned I would have great times now if I was over at the town. The June rise used to be always luck for me; because as soon as that rise begins here comes cordwood floating down, and pieces of log rafts—sometimes a dozen logs together; so all you have to do is to catch them and sell them to the wood-yards and the sawmill.
I went along up the bank with one eye out for pap and t’other one out for what the rise might fetch along. Well, all at once here comes a canoe; just a beauty, too, about thirteen or fourteen foot long, riding high like a duck. I shot head-first off of the bank like a frog, clothes and all on, and struck out for the canoe. I just expected there’d be somebody laying down in it, because people often done that to fool folks, and when a chap had pulled a skiff out most to it they’d raise up and laugh at him. But it warn’t so this time. It was a drift-canoe sure enough, and I clumb in and paddled her ashore. Thinks I, the old man will be glad when he sees this—she’s worth ten dollars. But when I got to shore pap wasn’t in sight yet, and as I was running her into a little creek like a gully, all hung over with vines and willows, I struck another idea: I judged I’d hide her good, and then, ’stead of taking to the woods when I run off, I’d go down the river about fifty mile and camp in one place for good, and not have such a rough time tramping on foot.
It was pretty close to the shanty, and I thought I heard the old man coming all the time; but I got her hid; and then I out and looked around a bunch of willows, and there was the old man down the path a piece just drawing a bead on a bird with his gun. So he hadn’t seen anything.
When he got along I was hard at it taking up a “trot” line. He abused me a little for being so slow; but I told him I fell in the river, and that was what made me so long. I knowed he would see I was wet, and then he would be asking questions. We got five catfish off the lines and went home.

"Git up! What you ’bout?"  

The voice startled me awake, and I sat up quick, rubbing my eyes. It was still dark, but I could make out the figure of Jim standing over me, his face tight with worry.  

"I hear somethin', Huck," he whispered. "Ain't right. Sounds like men comin'."  

I held my breath and listened. Sure enough, faint voices carried over the river, along with the soft splash of oars. My heart started pounding like a drum. We’d been careful, hiding our raft during the day and only moving at night, but somebody must’ve spotted us.  

"We gotta move," I said, scrambling to my feet. Jim was already pulling up the anchor, his hands working fast. The raft creaked as it shifted in the water, and I grabbed the pole, pushing us away from the bank. The current caught us quick, and we drifted into the middle of the river, keeping low so nobody’d see us.  

The voices got louder. I peeked over the edge of the raft and saw a lantern bobbing on the water—a skiff with two men in it, rowing slow like they was searching for something.  

"Keep down," Jim breathed, and I flattened myself against the wet planks. The raft swayed, and I held on tight, praying they wouldn’t spot us.  

One of the men spoke up, his voice rough. "Ain’t nothin’ here. Must’ve been a log or somethin’."  

The other grunted. "Reckon so. But old Mister Watson swore he seen a runaway nigger and a white boy on a raft this way."  

My blood ran cold. They was looking for *us*.  

The skiff drifted closer, so near I could hear the water dripping off their oars. Jim didn’t move a muscle, his face pressed into the wood. I shut my eyes, waiting for the shout that’d give us away.  

Then—blessed luck—a fish jumped nearby with a loud splash.  

"Aw, hell," the first man muttered. "Just fish. Let’s head back."  

The skiff turned, the lantern light fading as they rowed away. I let out a long breath, my whole body shaking.  

Jim sat up slow. "That was too close," he said.  

I nodded, still too scared to speak. The river was supposed to be our freedom, but it was full of dangers—men with guns, slave catchers, and who knew what else.  

"We best keep movin’," Jim said after a minute. "Sun’ll be up soon."  

I took the pole again, steering us further downstream. The sky was starting to lighten in the east, turning from black to gray. Somewhere up ahead, there’d be another place to hide, another day to get through.  

Jim looked at me, his eyes serious. "Huck, you reckon we’ll ever be safe?"  

I didn’t know the answer. But I knew one thing for sure—I wasn’t going back. Not to the Widow Douglas, not to Pap, not to any of it.  

"We’ll make it, Jim," I said, though I wasn’t sure I believed it myself. "We just gotta keep goin’."  

And with that, the raft carried us on, the river whispering secrets we couldn’t yet understand.

events.title: Formulating the Escape Plan and Seizing an Opportunity
detailed_summary: While resting after breakfast, Huck contemplates a method to prevent Pap and the Widow Douglas from searching for him after his escape.
Pap's gruff remark about wishing he had shot a supposed prowler inadvertently gives Huck the core idea for his elaborate deception.
The river continues to rise, bringing a raft of nine logs, which Huck and Pap secure.
True to his nature, Pap decides to take the logs to town immediately to sell them, rather than waiting for more salvage.
Pap locks Huck inside the cabin before departing with the logs, an action Huck anticipates will keep Pap away overnight.
Once he believes Pap is a safe distance away, Huck uses his saw to resume cutting a hole in the cabin wall, completing his exit before Pap's raft is out of sight.

While we laid off after breakfast to sleep up, both of us being about wore out, I got to thinking that if I could fix up some way to keep pap and the widow from trying to follow me, it would be a certainer thing than trusting to luck to get far enough off before they missed me; you see, all kinds of things might happen. Well, I didn’t see no way for a while, but by-and-by pap raised up a minute to drink another barrel of water, and he says:
“Another time a man comes a-prowling round here you roust me out, you hear? That man warn’t here for no good. I’d a shot him. Next time you roust me out, you hear?”
Then he dropped down and went to sleep again; but what he had been saying give me the very idea I wanted. I says to myself, I can fix it now so nobody won’t think of following me.
About twelve o’clock we turned out and went along up the bank. The river was coming up pretty fast, and lots of driftwood going by on the rise. By-and-by along comes part of a log raft—nine logs fast together. We went out with the skiff and towed it ashore. Then we had dinner. Anybody but pap would a waited and seen the day through, so as to catch more stuff; but that warn’t pap’s style. Nine logs was enough for one time; he must shove right over to town and sell. So he locked me in and took the skiff, and started off towing the raft about half-past three. I judged he wouldn’t come back that night. I waited till I reckoned he had got a good start; then I out with my saw, and went to work on that log again. Before he was t’other side of the river I was out of the hole; him and his raft was just a speck on the water away off yonder.

While we laid off after breakfast to sleep up, both of us being about wore out, I got to thinking that if I could fix up some way to keep pap and the widow from trying to follow me, it would be a certainer thing than trusting to luck to get far enough off before they missed me; you see, all kinds of things might happen.  

I reckoned pap would be madder than a hornet when he found me gone, and the widow, well, she’d likely send somebody after me, thinking I’d been kidnapped or worse. Jim stirred in his sleep, and I hushed up my thinking. Maybe the best plan was no plan at all—just keep moving fast and far. Still, the thought of them hunting me down like a fox with hounds on its trail made me uneasy. Luck was a fickle thing, and I’d need more than luck to stay free.

events.title: Securing Provisions and Erasing Traces
detailed_summary: Huck systematically transfers all valuable provisions from the cabin to his hidden canoe.
His haul includes food staples like corn meal and bacon, whiskey, coffee, sugar, as well as ammunition, tools like his old saw, blankets, and cooking utensils.
He consciously decides to leave the woodpile axe, having a specific purpose for it in his plan.
After clearing out the cabin, Huck meticulously camouflages his escape route.
He scatters dust to hide the smoothness and sawdust around the hole he crawled through.
He carefully replaces the sawed-out log section, propping it with rocks to appear undisturbed from the outside, especially since it's at the less-visited back of the cabin.

I took the sack of corn meal and took it to where the canoe was hid, and shoved the vines and branches apart and put it in; then I done the same with the side of bacon; then the whisky-jug. I took all the coffee and sugar there was, and all the ammunition; I took the wadding; I took the bucket and gourd; I took a dipper and a tin cup, and my old saw and two blankets, and the skillet and the coffee-pot. I took fish-lines and matches and other things—everything that was worth a cent. I cleaned out the place. I wanted an axe, but there wasn’t any, only the one out at the woodpile, and I knowed why I was going to leave that. I fetched out the gun, and now I was done.
I had wore the ground a good deal crawling out of the hole and dragging out so many things. So I fixed that as good as I could from the outside by scattering dust on the place, which covered up the smoothness and the sawdust. Then I fixed the piece of log back into its place, and put two rocks under it and one against it to hold it there, for it was bent up at that place and didn’t quite touch ground. If you stood four or five foot away and didn’t know it was sawed, you wouldn’t never notice it; and besides, this was the back of the cabin, and it warn’t likely anybody would go fooling around there.

detailed_summary: Huck verifies that he left no tracks leading from the cabin to the canoe's hiding spot.
He hunts and shoots a wild pig in the nearby woods.
Returning to the cabin, he uses an axe to violently smash in the door, simulating a forced entry.
He brings the pig inside and cuts its throat, allowing it to bleed onto the cabin's earthen floor to create the appearance of a murder.
To suggest his body was disposed of in the river, Huck fills an old sack with heavy rocks, drags it from the pig across the floor and through the woods to the riverbank, and then sinks it.
He reflects that Tom Sawyer would have appreciated and enhanced such a dramatic setup with his imaginative flair.

events.title: Elaborate Misdirection and Final Preparations
detailed_summary: Huck adds final, gruesome details to his staged murder by pulling out some of his own hair and smearing blood on the axe, which he then leaves in a corner of the cabin.
He carries the pig's carcass some distance downstream from the cabin before throwing it into the river, ensuring it won't be easily found near the 'crime scene'.
Thinking further, he retrieves the bag of cornmeal and his saw from the canoe.

He rips a hole in the bottom of the meal sack and creates a trail of sifted meal from the cabin, across the grass, and towards a large, shallow lake, intending to suggest robbers fled that way with stolen goods.
He strategically drops Pap's whetstone along this trail to make the scene appear more convincing.
After tying up the hole in the sack, he returns it and the saw to the canoe.
As darkness settles, Huck moves the canoe further downriver, concealing it under overhanging willows, and waits for the moon to rise.
He reviews his plan, confident that the false trails will mislead anyone searching for him, making them believe he was murdered and his body and belongings taken away from the river.
He identifies Jackson's Island as his intended sanctuary.

Well, last I pulled out some of my hair, and blooded the axe good, and stuck it on the back side, and slung the axe in the corner. Then I took up the pig and held him to my breast with my jacket (so he couldn’t drip) till I got a good piece below the house and then dumped him into the river. Now I thought of something else. So I went and got the bag of meal and my old saw out of the canoe, and fetched them to the house. I took the bag to where it used to stand, and ripped a hole in the bottom of it with the saw, for there warn’t no knives and forks on the place—pap done everything with his clasp-knife about the cooking. Then I carried the sack about a hundred yards across the grass and through the willows east of the house, to a shallow lake that was five mile wide and full of rushes—and ducks too, you might say, in the season. There was a slough or a creek leading out of it on the other side that went miles away, I don’t know where, but it didn’t go to the river. The meal sifted out and made a little track all the way to the lake. I dropped pap’s whetstone there too, so as to look like it had been done by accident. Then I tied up the rip in the meal sack with a string, so it wouldn’t leak no more, and took it and my saw to the canoe again.
It was about dark now; so I dropped the canoe down the river under some willows that hung over the bank, and waited for the moon to rise. I made fast to a willow; then I took a bite to eat, and by-and-by laid down in the canoe to smoke a pipe and lay out a plan. I says to myself, they’ll follow the track of that sackful of rocks to the shore and then drag the river for me. And they’ll follow that meal track to the lake and go browsing down the creek that leads out of it to find the robbers that killed me and took the things. They won’t ever hunt the river for anything but my dead carcass. They’ll soon get tired of that, and won’t bother no more about me. All right; I can stop anywhere I want to. Jackson’s Island is good enough for me; I know that island pretty well, and nobody ever comes there. And then I can paddle over to town nights, and slink around and pick up things I want. Jackson’s Island’s the place.

events.title: An Unexpected Encounter and a Narrow Escape
detailed_summary: Huck wakes up in his canoe, momentarily disoriented, then remembers his circumstances and his elaborate escape.
The river is vast under a bright moon, and the night is profoundly quiet.
He hears the distinct sound of oars and spots a skiff moving across the water.
As it draws nearer, he recognizes the lone occupant as Pap, who is unexpectedly returning and appears to be sober from the way he handles the oars.
Reacting instantly, Huck silently and swiftly paddles his canoe downstream, hidden by the riverbank's shadows, just as Pap passes by.
He navigates two and a half miles before steering towards the middle of the river to avoid detection near the ferry landing, then lies down in the canoe to drift.

events.text_segment:
I was pretty tired, and the first thing I knowed I was asleep. When I woke up I didn’t know where I was for a minute. I set up and looked around, a little scared. Then I remembered. The river looked miles and miles across. The moon was so bright I could a counted the drift logs that went a-slipping along, black and still, hundreds of yards out from shore. Everything was dead quiet, and it looked late, and smelt late. You know what I mean—I don’t know the words to put it in.
I took a good gap and a stretch, and was just going to unhitch and start when I heard a sound away over the water. I listened. Pretty soon I made it out. It was that dull kind of a regular sound that comes from oars working in rowlocks when it’s a still night. I peeped out through the willow branches, and there it was—a skiff, away across the water. I couldn’t tell how many was in it. It kept a-coming, and when it was abreast of me I see there warn’t but one man in it. Think’s I, maybe it’s pap, though I warn’t expecting him. He dropped below me with the current, and by-and-by he came a-swinging up shore in the easy water, and he went by so close I could a reached out the gun and touched him. Well, it was pap, sure enough—and sober, too, by the way he laid his oars.
I didn’t lose no time. The next minute I was a-spinning down stream soft but quick in the shade of the bank. I made two mile and a half, and then struck out a quarter of a mile or more towards the middle of the river, because pretty soon I would be passing the ferry landing, and people might see me and hail me. I got out amongst the driftwood, and then laid down in the bottom of the canoe and let her float.

events.title: Huck Observes the Search Party and Finds Sustenance
detailed_summary: Huck awakens late in the morning, feeling rested and content in the shade of the trees.
He notices sunlight filtering through the leaves and squirrels chattering nearby.
Feeling lazy, he is about to doze off again when he hears a distant cannon boom.
He realizes a ferry-boat is on the river, with people firing cannons to make his supposed drowned body surface.
Though hungry, Huck decides against starting a fire to avoid detection by the smoke.
He recalls the custom of floating loaves of bread with quicksilver inside to locate drowned bodies.
He moves to the Illinois side of the island and successfully retrieves a loaf of baker's bread from the river using a stick.
After removing the quicksilver, he eats the bread, reflecting that the Widow or Parson's prayers might have led the bread to him, validating their faith but not his own.

events.text_segment:
The sun was up so high when I waked that I judged it was after eight o’clock. I laid there in the grass and the cool shade thinking about things, and feeling rested and ruther comfortable and satisfied. I could see the sun out at one or two holes, but mostly it was big trees all about, and gloomy in there amongst them. There was freckled places on the ground where the light sifted down through the leaves, and the freckled places swapped about a little, showing there was a little breeze up there. A couple of squirrels set on a limb and jabbered at me very friendly.
I was powerful lazy and comfortable—didn’t want to get up and cook breakfast. Well, I was dozing off again when I thinks I hears a deep sound of “boom!” away up the river. I rouses up, and rests on my elbow and listens; pretty soon I hears it again. I hopped up, and went and looked out at a hole in the leaves, and I see a bunch of smoke laying on the water a long ways up—about abreast the ferry. And there was the ferry-boat full of people floating along down. I knowed what was the matter now. “Boom!” I see the white smoke squirt out of the ferry-boat’s side. You see, they was firing cannon over the water, trying to make my carcass come to the top.
I was pretty hungry, but it warn’t going to do for me to start a fire, because they might see the smoke. So I set there and watched the cannon-smoke and listened to the boom. The river was a mile wide there, and it always looks pretty on a summer morning—so I was having a good enough time seeing them hunt for my remainders if I only had a bite to eat. Well, then I happened to think how they always put quicksilver in loaves of bread and float them off, because they always go right to the drownded carcass and stop there. So, says I, I’ll keep a lookout, and if any of them’s floating around after me I’ll give them a show. I changed to the Illinois edge of the island to see what luck I could have, and I warn’t disappointed. A big double loaf come along, and I most got it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and she floated out further. Of course I was where the current set in the closest to the shore—I knowed enough for that. But by-and-by along comes another one, and this time I won. I took out the plug and shook out the little dab of quicksilver, and set my teeth in. It was “baker’s bread”—what the quality eat; none of your low-down corn-pone.
I got a good place amongst the leaves, and set there on a log, munching the bread and watching the ferry-boat, and very well satisfied.

So there ain’t no doubt but there is something in that thing—that is, there’s something in it when a body like the widow or the parson prays, but it don’t work for me, and I reckon it don’t work for only just the right kind.
I lit a pipe and had a good long smoke, and went on watching. The ferry-boat was floating with the current, and I allowed I’d have a chance to see who was aboard when she come along, because she would come in close, where the bread did. Where the log forked I could peep through.
By-and-by she come along, and she drifted in so close that they could a run out a plank and walked ashore. Most everybody was on the boat. Pap, and Judge Thatcher, and Bessie Thatcher, and Jo Harper, and Tom Sawyer, and his old Aunt Polly, and Sid and Mary, and plenty more. Everybody was talking about the murder, but the captain broke in and says:
“Look sharp, now; the current sets in the closest here, and maybe he’s washed ashore and got tangled amongst the brush at the water’s edge. I hope so, anyway.”
I didn’t hope so. They all crowded up and leaned over the rails, nearly in my face, and kept still, watching with all their might. I could see them first-rate, but they couldn’t see me. Then the captain sung out:
“Stand away!” and the cannon let off such a blast right before me that it made me deef with the noise and pretty near blind with the smoke, and I judged I was gone. If they’d a had some bullets in, I reckon they’d a got the corpse they was after. Well, I see I warn’t hurt, thanks to goodness. The boat floated on and went out of sight around the shoulder of the island. I could hear the booming now and then, further and further off, and by-and-by, after an hour, I didn’t hear it no more. The island was three mile long. I judged they had got to the foot, and was giving it up.

And then something struck me. Maybe I had been wrong about Jim all along. Here he was, risking everything to help me—risking his own freedom just to keep me safe. All this time, I’d been taught that slaves weren’t supposed to think for themselves, that they weren’t supposed to care about folks like me. But Jim did. He cared more than most white folks I knew.  

I remembered the way he’d looked out for me on the river, how he’d let me sleep while he kept watch, how he’d scolded me when I played tricks on him, not out of anger, but because he didn’t want me to grow up mean. He was more of a father to me than Pap ever was. And yet, the law said he belonged to somebody else, like he was a piece of property instead of a man.  

The more I thought on it, the sicker I felt. Here I was, helping a runaway slave, and all the while, my conscience had been gnawing at me, telling me I was doing wrong. But what if the real wrong was the way folks treated Jim in the first place? What if the whole system was twisted, and I was just starting to see it?  

I reckoned Miss Watson would say I was bound for hell, and maybe I was. But if helping Jim get free was a sin, then I didn’t want to be good. I’d rather go to hell than turn my back on him now.  

Jim stirred in his sleep, mumbling something about his wife and children. My chest tightened. He had a family—people he loved and missed. How could anybody say he didn’t have the right to be with them?  

I made up my mind then and there. No matter what happened, I wasn’t going to let Jim down. If that meant lying to slave hunters or outsmarting the law, then so be it. Some things were more important than rules.

events.title: Huck Establishes Camp and Begins Solitary Island Life
detailed_summary: The search party, however, circles the island and heads up the Missouri side, still occasionally firing the cannon, before finally returning to town.
Feeling secure, Huck retrieves his belongings from his canoe and sets up a comfortable camp in the dense woods, using blankets to create a tent.
He catches a catfish, prepares it, and cooks supper over a campfire as sundown approaches.
He sets out a fishing line for the next day's breakfast.
As darkness falls, he smokes by his fire, feeling satisfied, but a sense of loneliness creeps in.
He counters this by sitting on the riverbank, listening to the water, and observing the stars and passing debris before going to bed.
He reflects that this routine helps overcome loneliness.
This pattern continues for three days and nights.
On the fourth day, he decides to explore the island thoroughly, partly to know his domain and partly to pass the time.
During his exploration, he finds an abundance of strawberries, green grapes, green raspberries, and nascent blackberries, anticipating their future usefulness.

But they didn’t yet a while. They turned around the foot of the island and started up the channel on the Missouri side, under steam, and booming once in a while as they went. I crossed over to that side and watched them. When they got abreast the head of the island they quit shooting and dropped over to the Missouri shore and went home to the town.
I knowed I was all right now. Nobody else would come a-hunting after me. I got my traps out of the canoe and made me a nice camp in the thick woods. I made a kind of a tent out of my blankets to put my things under so the rain couldn’t get at them. I catched a catfish and haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp fire and had supper. Then I set out a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
When it was dark I set by my camp fire smoking, and feeling pretty well satisfied; but by-and-by it got sort of lonesome, and so I went and set on the bank and listened to the current swashing along, and counted the stars and drift logs and rafts that come down, and then went to bed; there ain’t no better way to put in time when you are lonesome; you can’t stay so, you soon get over it.
And so for three days and nights. No difference—just the same thing. But the next day I went exploring around down through the island. I was boss of it; it all belonged to me, so to say, and I wanted to know all about it; but mainly I wanted to put in the time. I found plenty strawberries, ripe and prime; and green summer grapes, and green razberries; and the green blackberries was just beginning to show. They would all come handy by-and-by, I judged.

But they didn’t yet a while. The river was high, and the current strong, so Huck and Jim had to keep a sharp lookout for snags and floating logs. The raft moved slow, but steady, and the nights were peaceful under the stars. Jim nodded, his face serious. “Sounds like trouble, Huck. Best we steer clear.”

Huck’s heart pounded. “Reckon there’s anybody aboard?”  

Jim shook his head. “Ain’t likely. But we best move on quick—ain’t no good comes from messin’ with wrecks.”

“We can’t just leave ’em,” Huck said.  

Jim sighed. “No, we can’t. But this ain’t gonna end well, Huck. Mark my words.”

events.title: Discovery of a Smoldering Campfire and Huck's Fearful Reaction
detailed_summary: While exploring near the foot of the island with his gun for protection, Huck nearly steps on a large snake.
Chasing after the snake, he unexpectedly stumbles upon the still-smoking ashes of a campfire.
His heart races with fear; he immediately unocks his gun and stealthily retreats, his heightened senses making him paranoid.
Reaching his camp feeling unnerved, he quickly packs his belongings back into the canoe, extinguishes his fire, and camouflages the ashes to appear old.
He then climbs a tree and remains there for about two hours, anxiously observing and imagining threats.
Eventually, he descends but stays within the dense woods, remaining vigilant and subsisting on berries and leftover breakfast.
By nightfall, hunger drives him to paddle to the Illinois bank under the cover of darkness to cook supper.
Just as he considers staying there overnight, he hears the sound of horses and people's voices approaching.
He hastily repacks his canoe and creeps through the woods to investigate, overhearing men discussing camping nearby due to tired horses.
Without waiting further, Huck quietly paddles back to his original spot on the island, deciding to sleep in the canoe for safety.

Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far from the foot of the island. I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh home. About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it, trying to get a shot at it. I clipped along, and all of a sudden I bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
My heart jumped up amongst my lungs. I never waited for to look further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as fast as ever I could. Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear nothing else. I slunk along another piece further, then listened again; and so on, and so on. If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around. So I got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight, and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I didn’t hear nothing—I only thought I heard and seen as much as a thousand things. Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the time. All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from breakfast.
By the time it was night I was pretty hungry. So when it was good and dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile. I went out in the woods and cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all night when I hear a plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk, and says to myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices. I got everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping through the woods to see what I could find out. I hadn’t got far when I hear a man say:
“We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about beat out. Let’s look around.”
I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy. I tied up in the old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.

He near about jumped out of his skin. He whipped around, eyes wide as saucers, and then he saw it was me. “Huck Finn!” he gasped. “Good Lord, you scared the life outta me! What you doin’ here?”

“Same as you, I reckon,” I said, sitting down by the fire. “Running away.”

Jim looked at me real serious. “Ain’t you afraid your pap’ll come after you?”

I shrugged. “He can try. But I ain’t going back, not ever.”

Jim nodded slow, like he understood. Then he said, “Well, you’s welcome to stay here with me, if you wants. Ain’t no good bein’ alone out here.”

We talked a while, and Jim told me how he’d been hiding on the island a few days, living off fish and berries. He had a little raft hidden down by the river, and he was fixing to float down to Cairo, where he could be free.

“You could come with me, Huck,” he said. “We could look out for each other.”

“All right,” I said at last. “I’ll go with you.”

He bounced up and stared at me wild. Then he drops down on his knees, and puts his hands together and says:
“Doan’ hurt me—don’t! I hain’t ever done no harm to a ghos’. I alwuz liked dead people, en done all I could for ’em. You go en git in de river agin, whah you b’longs, en doan’ do nuffn to Ole Jim, ’at ’uz awluz yo’ fren’.”
Well, I warn’t long making him understand I warn’t dead. I was ever so glad to see Jim. I warn’t lonesome now. I told him I warn’t afraid of him telling the people where I was. I talked along, but he only set there and looked at me; never said nothing. Then I says:
“It’s good daylight. Le’s get breakfast. Make up your camp fire good.”
“What’s de use er makin’ up de camp fire to cook strawbries en sich truck? But you got a gun, hain’t you? Den we kin git sumfn better den strawbries.”
“Strawberries and such truck,” I says. “Is that what you live on?”
“I couldn’ git nuffn else,” he says.
“Why, how long you been on the island, Jim?”
“I come heah de night arter you’s killed.”
“What, all that time?”
“Yes—indeedy.”
“And ain’t you had nothing but that kind of rubbage to eat?”
“No, sah—nuffn else.”
“Well, you must be most starved, ain’t you?”
“I reck’n I could eat a hoss. I think I could. How long you ben on de islan’?”
“Since the night I got killed.”
“No! W’y, what has you lived on? But you got a gun. Oh, yes, you got a gun. Dat’s good. Now you kill sumfn en I’ll make up de fire.”

He bounced up and stared at me wild. His eyes were wide, and his face was pale as a sheet. For a second, I thought he might bolt right out of the cabin, but he just stood there, trembling like a leaf in a storm.  

“Huck Finn!” he gasped. “You—you’re alive!”  

I reckon I must’ve looked as surprised as he did. “Course I’m alive,” I said. “Why wouldn’t I be?”  

Jim shook his head, still staring like he’d seen a ghost. “Dey was sayin’ you was kilt! Dat somebody done shot you down by de river!”  

Well, that explained it. Some fool rumor had got around, and Jim had believed it. I couldn’t help but grin a little. “Ain’t nobody shot me,” I told him. “I been layin’ low, that’s all.”  

Jim let out a long breath and sat down hard on the floor, like his legs had given out. “Lawd have mercy,” he muttered. “I been grievin’ over you, Huck. Thought I lost my best friend.”  

Hearing that made my chest feel tight. Jim was the truest friend I ever had, and here he’d been mourning me while I was off having adventures. I sat down beside him. “I’m sorry you was worried,” I said. “Didn’t mean to scare you.”  

Jim looked at me then, real serious. “Don’t you go disappearin’ like dat again,” he said. “A body can’t take dat kinda fright.”  

I nodded. “I won’t,” I promised. And I meant it.

events.title: Jim Recounts His Escape from Slavery
detailed_summary: While Jim builds a fire, Huck retrieves provisions from his canoe—meal, bacon, coffee, and cooking utensils—which greatly astonishes Jim, who attributes it to witchcraft.
Huck catches a large catfish, which Jim cleans and fries.
They enjoy a hearty breakfast, with Jim eating voraciously due to his near starvation.
After eating, Jim asks Huck about the 'murder' in the shanty if it wasn't Huck.
Huck explains his elaborate escape plan, which Jim praises as clever, even beyond Tom Sawyer's abilities.
Huck then inquires how Jim came to be on the island.
Jim hesitates, then, after Huck promises not to betray him, confesses he ran off.
Huck, despite societal condemnation of helping a runaway slave, vows to keep Jim's secret.
Jim explains that Miss Watson, despite often treating him roughly, had always said she wouldn't sell him to New Orleans.
However, he grew uneasy seeing a slave trader around and overheard Miss Watson telling the Widow Douglas she was going to sell him for $800, a sum she couldn't resist.
Without waiting to hear more, Jim fled immediately.
He hid in an old cooper-shop, intending to steal a skiff, but people were still about.
The next morning, he heard news of Huck's 'murder' from people going to see the scene.
He remained hidden all day, hungry but not afraid, knowing Miss Watson and the Widow were at a camp-meeting.
At nightfall, he walked up the river road, deciding a raft was his best means of escape as it leaves no tracks.
He swam out to a passing raft, hid on board, and planned to swim ashore on the Illinois side further downriver.
His plan was thwarted when a man with a lantern approached his hiding spot on the raft as they neared the island, forcing Jim to slide overboard and swim to the island.

He struggled to find a landing spot due to bluff banks but eventually made it ashore and decided to abandon further attempts with rafts due to the risk of discovery by lantern light, content with his pipe, tobacco, and dry matches.

So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft. I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.
When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot. Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved. Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied. By-and-by Jim says:
“But looky here, Huck, who wuz it dat ’uz killed in dat shanty ef it warn’t you?”
Then I told him the whole thing, and he said it was smart. He said Tom Sawyer couldn’t get up no better plan than what I had. Then I says:
“How do you come to be here, Jim, and how’d you get here?”
He looked pretty uneasy, and didn’t say nothing for a minute. Then he says:
“Maybe I better not tell.”
“Why, Jim?”
“Well, dey’s reasons. But you wouldn’ tell on me ef I uz to tell you, would you, Huck?”
“Blamed if I would, Jim.”
“Well, I b’lieve you, Huck. I—I run off.”
“Jim!”
“But mind, you said you wouldn’ tell—you know you said you wouldn’ tell, Huck.”
“Well, I did. I said I wouldn’t, and I’ll stick to it. Honest injun, I will. People would call me a low-down Abolitionist and despise me for keeping mum—but that don’t make no difference. I ain’t a-going to tell, and I ain’t a-going back there, anyways. So, now, le’s know all about it.”
“Well, you see, it ’uz dis way. Ole missus—dat’s Miss Watson—she pecks on me all de time, en treats me pooty rough, but she awluz said she wouldn’ sell me down to Orleans. But I noticed dey wuz a nigger trader roun’ de place considable lately, en I begin to git oneasy. Well, one night I creeps to de do’ pooty late, en de do’ warn’t quite shet, en I hear old missus tell de widder she gwyne to sell me down to Orleans, but she didn’ want to, but she could git eight hund’d dollars for me, en it ’uz sich a big stack o’ money she couldn’ resis’. De widder she try to git her to say she wouldn’ do it, but I never waited to hear de res’. I lit out mighty quick, I tell you.
“I tuck out en shin down de hill, en ’spec to steal a skift ’long de sho’ som’ers ’bove de town, but dey wuz people a-stirring yit, so I hid in de ole tumble-down cooper-shop on de bank to wait for everybody to go ’way. Well, I wuz dah all night. Dey wuz somebody roun’ all de time. ’Long ’bout six in de mawnin’ skifts begin to go by, en ’bout eight er nine every skift dat went ’long wuz talkin’ ’bout how yo’ pap come over to de town en say you’s killed. Dese las’ skifts wuz full o’ ladies en genlmen a-goin’ over for to see de place. Sometimes dey’d pull up at de sho’ en take a res’ b’fo’ dey started acrost, so by de talk I got to know all ’bout de killin’. I ’uz powerful sorry you’s killed, Huck, but I ain’t no mo’ now.
“I laid dah under de shavin’s all day. I ’uz hungry, but I warn’t afeard; bekase I knowed ole missus en de widder wuz goin’ to start to de camp-meet’n’ right arter breakfas’ en be gone all day, en dey knows I goes off wid de cattle ’bout daylight, so dey wouldn’ ’spec to see me roun’ de place, en so dey wouldn’ miss me tell arter dark in de evenin’. De yuther servants wouldn’ miss me, kase dey’d shin out en take holiday soon as de ole folks ’uz out’n de way.
“Well, when it come dark I tuck out up de river road, en went ’bout two mile er more to whah dey warn’t no houses. I’d made up my mine ’bout what I’s agwyne to do. You see, ef I kep’ on tryin’ to git away afoot, de dogs ’ud track me; ef I stole a skift to cross over, dey’d miss dat skift, you see, en dey’d know ’bout whah I’d lan’ on de yuther side, en whah to pick up my track. So I says, a raff is what I’s arter; it doan’ make no track.
“I see a light a-comin’ roun’ de p’int bymeby, so I wade’ in en shove’ a log ahead o’ me en swum more’n half way acrost de river, en got in ’mongst de drift-wood, en kep’ my head down low, en kinder swum agin de current tell de raff come along. Den I swum to de stern uv it en tuck a-holt. It clouded up en ’uz pooty dark for a little while. So I clumb up en laid down on de planks. De men ’uz all ’way yonder in de middle, whah de lantern wuz. De river wuz a-risin’, en dey wuz a good current; so I reck’n’d ’at by fo’ in de mawnin’ I’d be twenty-five mile down de river, en den I’d slip in jis b’fo’ daylight en swim asho’, en take to de woods on de Illinois side.
“But I didn’ have no luck. When we ’uz mos’ down to de head er de islan’ a man begin to come aft wid de lantern, I see it warn’t no use fer to wait, so I slid overboard en struck out fer de islan’. Well, I had a notion I could lan’ mos’ anywhers, but I couldn’t—bank too bluff. I ’uz mos’ to de foot er de islan’ b’fo’ I found’ a good place. I went into de woods en jedged I wouldn’ fool wid raffs no mo’, long as dey move de lantern roun’ so. I had my pipe en a plug er dog-leg, en some matches in my cap, en dey warn’t wet, so I ’uz all right.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft.  

Jim—that was his name—just stood there with his mouth open, staring at me like I’d pulled the moon down from the sky. “Huck,” he says, “how in the nation you manage all dat? One minute dere ain’t nothin’, and de next, dere’s a whole camp set up like magic!”  

I couldn’t help but grin. “Ain’t no magic, Jim. Just plain old fetchin’ and carryin’. You’d do the same if you was free to move about.”  

That word—*free*—hung in the air between us like a spark from the fire. Jim looked down at the ground, shuffling his feet. “Reckon I would,” he muttered.  

I felt a pang then, knowing what he was thinking. Here I was, talking about fetching and carrying like it was nothing, when Jim couldn’t so much as step off Miss Watson’s place without somebody hunting him down. It made me uneasy, but I didn’t let on.  

“Well,” I said, slapping my hands on my knees, “let’s get this grub cooked. I’m near about starved.”  

Jim nodded and set to work frying up the bacon while I mixed the meal into dough for ash-cakes. The fire crackled and popped, sending up little sparks that danced in the dark. The smell of bacon fat and coffee filled the clearing, and for a while, neither of us said much.  

After we’d eaten, Jim leaned back against a tree, sighing like a man who’d just had the best meal of his life. “Huck,” he said, “dis here’s mighty fine. I ain’t had no bacon since las’ Christmas.”  

I reckoned that was probably true. Slaves didn’t get much in the way of good eating, leastways not the ones I’d seen. “Well,” I said, “there’s plenty more where that came from. We’ll stock up when we can.”  

Jim looked at me then, real serious-like. “Huck, you reckon we gon’ make it?”  

I knew what he was asking. It wasn’t just about food or staying hidden—it was about the whole dang mess we’d gotten ourselves into. Running away with a slave was a hanging offense in some parts, and Jim knew it as well as I did.  

“Course we will,” I said, though I wasn’t near as sure as I sounded. “We got the river, and we got this canoe. Long as we keep moving and stay out of sight, ain’t nobody gon’ find us.”  

Jim didn’t look convinced, but he nodded anyway. “I hopes you right, Huck. I surely do.”  

We sat quiet for a spell, listening to the night sounds—the frogs croaking down by the water, the rustle of leaves in the breeze. Then Jim said, real soft, “You ever think ‘bout what’s waitin’ for us up yonder?”  

I knew he meant the free states. “Some,” I admitted. “But mostly I just think ‘bout keepin’ ahead of them that’s after us.”  

Jim sighed again. “I thinks ‘bout it all de time. ‘Bout workin’ for myself, savin’ up money to buy my wife and chillun outta slavery. Dat’s all I wants, Huck. Just to be free, and have my family wid me.”  

Hearing him talk like that made my chest ache. Here was a man who’d never done nobody no harm, just wanting what any man ought to have—his own life, his own family. And the law said he couldn’t have it, all on account of the color of his skin.  

I didn’t know what to say to that, so I just nodded. “We’ll get you there, Jim. One way or another.”  

He gave me a long look, then reached over and squeezed my shoulder. “You a good friend, Huck Finn.”  

I reckon that was about the finest thing anybody’d ever said to me.  

We bedded down not long after, spreading our blankets near the fire. The ground was hard, but I didn’t mind. For the first time in a long while, I felt like I was right where I was supposed to be.  

As I lay there, staring up at the stars through the trees, I got to thinking about Pap, and the Widow Douglas, and all the folks back in St. Petersburg who’d call me a no-good runaway if they knew where I was. But then I looked over at Jim, already snoring softly, and figured maybe being a runaway wasn’t such a bad thing after all.  

The river murmured in the distance, like it was whispering secrets just for us. Somewhere out there, the world was going on same as always—people buying and selling, preachers preaching, laws being made and broken. But here, on this little patch of ground by the fire, none of that mattered.  

For now, we were free.  

And that was enough.

events.title: Jim Discusses Superstitions and His Financial Misfortunes
detailed_summary: Huck asks Jim why he didn't eat turtles, and Jim explains the difficulty of catching them, especially at night or without revealing himself in daylight.
Jim confirms he heard the cannons being fired for Huck.
Jim points out young birds flying short distances as a sign of impending rain, a belief he extends from chickens.
He dissuades Huck from catching the birds, citing it as a sign of death, recalling an instance involving his father.
Jim shares other superstitions: counting food for dinner or shaking a tablecloth after sundown brings bad luck; bees must be informed of their owner's death to prevent them from dying.
Jim claims bees won't sting idiots, a notion Huck doubts from personal experience.
Huck notes that Jim knows many signs, mostly related to bad luck.
When asked about good luck signs, Jim mentions few, like hairy arms and breast signifying future wealth, which can offer comfort during long periods of poverty.
Jim confirms he has hairy arms and breast and claims to have been rich once (with fourteen dollars) and expects to be rich again.
He recounts his financial speculations: he lost money on a cow that died, only recouping a small amount from the hide.

He then invested his remaining money with a one-legged man named Bradish who started a 'bank,' promising a large return, but the bank 'busted' after Jim had also 'bought' a stolen wood-flat with the anticipated earnings.

His last ten cents were given to a man called 'Balum's Ass' for investment, based on a dream, after Balum heard a preacher say giving to the poor is lending to the Lord with a hundredfold return; the money was given to the poor but never seen again.
Jim concludes by stating that, in a way, he is rich now because he owns himself and is worth eight hundred dollars, wishing he had the cash equivalent.

“And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”
“How you gwyne to git ’m? You can’t slip up on um en grab um; en how’s a body gwyne to hit um wid a rock? How could a body do it in de night? En I warn’t gwyne to show mysef on de bank in de daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. You’ve had to keep in the woods all the time, of course. Did you hear ’em shooting the cannon?”
“Oh, yes. I knowed dey was arter you. I see um go by heah—watched um thoo de bushes.”
Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting. Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain. “And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”  

I reckon I must’ve looked right foolish, ‘cause I hadn’t thought of that. Mud-turkles—why, they was thick as fleas down by the riverbank, and easy enough to catch if a feller had a mind to. But I’d been so busy frettin’ over bein’ lost and dodgin’ folks that the notion hadn’t crossed my mind.  

“Well, I—I reckon I forgot,” I says, scratchin’ my head.  

Jim shook his head like I was the sorriest creature he ever laid eyes on. “Huck, sometimes I wonder ‘bout you. Here you is, starvin’ like a stray dog, and there’s food crawlin’ right under your nose. Ain’t you got no sense at all?”  

Now, that stung a little, but I couldn’t rightly argue. Jim had a way of makin’ me feel like a half-wit without even tryin’.  

“All right, all right,” I says, “next time I’ll remember the mud-turkles. But what about you? You been eatin’ good?”  

Jim puffed up a little at that, proud as a rooster. “You bet I has. I done caught me a mess o’ turkles just yesterday. Boiled ‘em up nice with some wild onions I found. Had myself a feast fit for a king.”  

That made my stomach growl somethin’ fierce. I hadn’t had a proper meal in days, and the thought of hot turtle stew set my mouth to waterin’.  

“You got any left?” I asked, tryin’ not to sound too desperate.  

Jim grinned. “Might be a scrap or two. ‘Course, I ain’t in the habit of feedin’ no ungrateful runaways who can’t even think to catch their own supper.”  

I knew he was funnin’ me, but I played along. “Aw, Jim, you know I’d do the same for you.”  

“Would you now?” he says, raisin’ an eyebrow. “Last I recall, you was the one lettin’ me do all the work while you lazed about like ol’ King Solomon hisself.”  

That wasn’t entirely fair, but I let it slide. Jim was in a good mood, and I wasn’t about to spoil it by arguin’. Besides, I was too hungry to care.  

“Tell you what,” Jim says after a minute, “I’ll share my vittles with you on one condition.”  

I should’ve known there was a catch. Jim was sharper than a tack when it came to bargains. “What’s that?” I asked, wary-like.  

“Next time we stop, you got to help me gather firewood and clean the turkles. Ain’t no free rides on this raft.”  

I heaved a sigh, but I knew he had me. “All right, it’s a deal.”  

Jim nodded, satisfied, and dug into his pack. He pulled out a little pot wrapped in a scrap of cloth and handed it to me. Inside was the last of his turtle stew, cold now but still smellin’ mighty fine.  

I didn’t waste no time. I scooped up a handful and stuffed it in my mouth before Jim could change his mind. It was greasy and a little gritty from the river sand, but I ain’t never tasted nothin’ so good in all my life.  

Jim watched me eat with a mix of amusement and pity. “Slow down, Huck, ‘fore you choke. Ain’t nobody gonna steal it from you.”  

I didn’t slow down. It wasn’t till I’d licked the pot clean that I finally came up for air.  

“Much obliged, Jim,” I says, wipin’ my mouth on my sleeve.  

He just shook his head again. “You is a caution, Huck Finn. A reg’lar caution.”  

I reckon he was right. But as I sat there with a full belly for the first time in days, listenin’ to the river lap against the raft and watchin’ the stars come out, I didn’t mind bein’ a caution one bit.  

Not one bit at all.

events.title: Discovery and Assessment of the Cavern
detailed_summary: Huck decided to show Jim a specific location he had previously discovered in the central part of the island.
The island itself was relatively small, making the journey to the spot quick.
The place was a moderately long and steep hill, about forty feet high, presenting a challenging climb due to its steepness and dense bushes.
After thorough exploration, they located a large cavern in the rock, positioned near the summit on the side facing Illinois.
The cavern was spacious, comparable to two or three combined rooms, allowing Jim to stand upright comfortably, and it offered a cool interior.
Jim immediately suggested moving their supplies into the cavern, but Huck expressed reservations about the inconvenience of constantly climbing to and from it.

events.title: Establishing a Secure Camp in the Cavern

Furthermore, Jim mentioned that small birds had indicated impending rain, questioning if Huck wanted their belongings to get wet.
Persuaded by Jim's reasoning, they retrieved their canoe.
They paddled the canoe to a point on the river adjacent to the cavern and laboriously transported all their supplies up to it.
After securing their belongings, they found a nearby, well-concealed spot among thick willows to hide the canoe.
They then attended to their fishing lines, taking some fish and resetting the lines, before starting preparations for their dinner.
The cavern's entrance was large enough for a hogshead to pass through, and a small, flat protrusion of the floor on one side of the entrance served as an ideal location for a fire.
They constructed their fire on this natural hearth and proceeded to cook their meal.

events.title: Sheltering from a Violent Storm in the Cavern
detailed_summary: They arranged their blankets inside the cavern to serve as a carpet and ate their dinner within its shelter.
All their other possessions were neatly stored at the back of the cavern.
Soon, the sky darkened, and thunder and lightning commenced, confirming the accuracy of the birds' prediction of rain.
A heavy downpour began, accompanied by exceptionally strong winds, characteristic of a typical summer storm.

Huck described the dramatic visual effects: the landscape appearing blue-black in the intense darkness, the thick rain obscuring distant trees into dim, web-like shapes, and powerful gusts of wind bending trees and revealing the pale undersides of their leaves.

He noted the branches thrashing wildly, followed by sudden, brilliant flashes of lightning that briefly illuminated treetops far off in the storm, then immediate, profound darkness again, and the awesome sound of thunder rolling across the sky.
Huck expressed his deep contentment to Jim, stating he desired to be nowhere else but their current refuge, and asked for more fish and cornbread.

Jim responded by reminding Huck that his present comfort and safety from being drenched in the woods were due to Jim's foresight and understanding of natural signs, like the behavior of chickens and birds before rain.

Jim smiled a little. "Best sleep while you can. Ain’t no tellin’ what tomorrow brings."

events.title: Navigating the Flooded Island and Finding a Raft
detailed_summary: The river continued to rise for approximately ten to twelve days, eventually overflowing its banks.
Water covered the low-lying areas of the island and the Illinois bottomlands to a depth of three or four feet.
On the Illinois side, the floodwaters spread out for many miles, while the Missouri side, with its high bluffs, maintained its usual half-mile width.
During the daytime, Huck and Jim used their canoe to navigate the flooded island.
They found the deep woods to be remarkably cool and shady, despite the blazing sun elsewhere.
Their explorations involved winding through the trees, sometimes having to retreat and find alternative paths due to thick vine growth.
They observed numerous rabbits, snakes, and other creatures on every old, fallen tree.

After a day or two of the island being submerged, these animals became quite tame from hunger, allowing Huck and Jim to approach and even touch them, though snakes and turtles would retreat into the water.
The ridge where their cavern was located was teeming with such wildlife.
One night, they managed to secure a small section of a lumber raft composed of good pine planks.
This raft section was about twelve feet wide and fifteen or sixteen feet long, with its top surface six or seven inches above the water, providing a solid, level platform.
They sometimes observed saw-logs floating by during the day but let them pass, as they were careful not to reveal their presence in daylight.

events.text_segment:
The river went on raising and raising for ten or twelve days, till at last it was over the banks. The water was three or four foot deep on the island in the low places and on the Illinois bottom. On that side it was a good many miles wide, but on the Missouri side it was the same old distance across—a half a mile—because the Missouri shore was just a wall of high bluffs.
Daytimes we paddled all over the island in the canoe, It was mighty cool and shady in the deep woods, even if the sun was blazing outside. We went winding in and out amongst the trees, and sometimes the vines hung so thick we had to back away and go some other way. Well, on every old broken-down tree you could see rabbits and snakes and such things; and when the island had been overflowed a day or two they got so tame, on account of being hungry, that you could paddle right up and put your hand on them if you wanted to; but not the snakes and turtles—they would slide off in the water. The ridge our cavern was in was full of them. We could a had pets enough if we’d wanted them.
One night we catched a little section of a lumber raft—nice pine planks. It was twelve foot wide and about fifteen or sixteen foot long, and the top stood above water six or seven inches—a solid, level floor. We could see saw-logs go by in the daylight sometimes, but we let them go; we didn’t show ourselves in daylight.

events.title: Exploring a Floating House and Discovering a Dead Man
detailed_summary: On another occasion, while they were at the northern end of the island near dawn, a two-story frame house came floating down the river on its west side, tilted significantly.
They paddled out to the house and climbed aboard through an upstairs window.
It was still too dark to see clearly, so they secured their canoe to the house and waited inside for daylight.
Light began to appear before they reached the southern end of the island.
Looking through the window, they could distinguish a bed, a table, two old chairs, various items scattered on the floor, and clothes hanging on the wall.
In a far corner, something lay on the floor that resembled a man.
Jim called out to the figure, but there was no response.
After Huck also shouted, Jim concluded that the man was not asleep but dead, and he went to investigate.
Jim bent down, looked closely, and confirmed it was a dead man, naked, who had been shot in the back and appeared to have been deceased for two or three days.
He advised Huck not to look at the man's face, describing it as too gruesome.
Huck chose not to look at the body at all; Jim covered it with some old rags, though Huck felt it unnecessary as he had no intention of looking.
The room contained scattered old, greasy playing cards, old whiskey bottles, and a pair of masks made from black cloth.
The walls were covered with crude words and pictures drawn with charcoal.
They found two old, dirty calico dresses, a sun-bonnet, women's undergarments, and some men's clothing hanging on the wall, all of which they took for the canoe, thinking it might be useful.
Huck also took an old, speckled straw hat belonging to a boy that was on the floor.
There was a broken milk bottle with a rag stopper, presumably for a baby.
A dilapidated old chest and an old hair trunk with broken hinges stood open, containing nothing of value, suggesting the occupants had left in a hurry without taking most of their possessions.

They salvaged an old tin lantern, a butcher knife missing its handle, a brand-new Barlow knife, numerous tallow candles, a tin candlestick, a gourd, a tin cup, a worn-out old bedquilt, a reticule filled with needles, pins, beeswax, buttons, and thread, a hatchet, some nails, a thick fishline with very large hooks, a roll of buckskin, a leather dog-collar, and a horseshoe.
They also found some vials of medicine without labels.
As they were about to leave, Huck found a reasonably good curry-comb, and Jim discovered an old, shabby fiddle-bow and a wooden leg.
The straps on the wooden leg were broken, but otherwise, it was serviceable, though it didn't fit either of them, and they couldn't find its match despite searching.

“De man ain’t asleep—he’s dead. You hold still—I’ll go en see.”
He went, and bent down and looked, and says:
“It’s a dead man. Yes, indeedy; naked, too. He’s ben shot in de back. I reck’n he’s ben dead two er three days. Come in, Huck, but doan’ look at his face—it’s too gashly.”
I didn’t look at him at all. Jim throwed some old rags over him, but he needn’t done it; I didn’t want to see him. We would a took the bottle, but it was broke. There was a seedy old chest, and an old hair trunk with the hinges broke. They stood open, but there warn’t nothing left in them that was any account. The way things was scattered about we reckoned the people left in a hurry, and warn’t fixed so as to carry off most of their stuff.

Another night when we was up at the head of the island, just before daylight, here comes a frame-house down, on the west side. It was a sight to see—that big old house a-floating along like some kind of ghost ship, all dark and silent. The river had swelled up something fierce, and the current must’ve tore it loose from its foundations. Now it was just drifting, slow and steady, like it didn’t have a care in the world.

Jim and me, we watched it come closer, our eyes wide as saucers. "Huck," Jim whispered, "you reckon there’s anybody in there?" 

I squinted at them dark windows. "Dunno," I says. "But if there is, they ain’t movin’ much." 

The house bumped up against the island, creaking like an old man’s bones. We waited a spell, listening hard, but there weren’t no sound from inside. "Might as well take a look," I said, and Jim, though he didn’t much like the idea, followed me as I waded out to it. 

The front door was hanging open, swaying with the river’s motion. Inside, it was all a mess—chairs overturned, a table smashed to pieces, and water sloshing over the floorboards. Then I seen something that near stopped my heart—a man lying in the corner, face down. 

"Jim!" I hissed. "There’s a dead man!" 

Jim crossed hisself quick. "Lord have mercy," he muttered. 

We crept closer, and that’s when I noticed the man weren’t alone. Another feller was sprawled nearby, his shirt all stained dark. The air was thick with the smell of wet wood and something else—something foul, like old meat. 

Jim tugged at my sleeve. "Huck, we best git. Ain’t no good come from messin’ with the dead." 

But I was curious. I bent down and turned the first man over—and near jumped clean out of my skin. His face was pale as chalk, his eyes staring at nothing. Then I seen the hole in his chest, ragged and ugly. "Jim, this feller’s been shot!" 

Jim’s eyes got even wider. "We *got* to go, Huck. This here’s bad business." 

Just then, the house groaned like it was fixing to break apart. The river was pushing at it, and the whole thing shifted sudden-like. We scrambled for the door, splashing through the water, and barely made it out before the house lurched sideways and started to sink. 

We stood on the bank, panting, watching as the river swallowed that house whole. The last thing I seen was the dead man’s hand sticking up out the window, like he was waving goodbye. Then it was gone. 

Jim was shaking his head. "That’s an omen, Huck. A mighty bad one." 

I didn’t say nothing, but I reckoned he was right. There was something awful about the way them men had died—like they’d been killed in a hurry and left there for the river to take. It put a chill in my bones, thinking on who might’ve done it and why. 

We didn’t talk much the rest of the morning. Just packed up our things and moved further down the island, putting distance between us and that cursed house. But I couldn’t shake the feeling that death was following us, floating down the river just like that house had been—quiet, and patient, and bound to catch up sooner or later.

After breakfast I wanted to talk about the dead man and guess out how he come to be killed, but Jim didn’t want to. He said it would fetch bad luck; and besides, he said, he might come and ha’nt us; he said a man that warn’t buried was more likely to go a-ha’nting around than one that was planted and comfortable. That sounded pretty reasonable, so I didn’t say no more; but I couldn’t keep from studying over it and wishing I knowed who shot the man, and what they done it for.
We rummaged the clothes we’d got, and found eight dollars in silver sewed up in the lining of an old blanket overcoat. Jim said he reckoned the people in that house stole the coat, because if they’d a knowed the money was there they wouldn’t a left it. I said I reckoned they killed him, too; but Jim didn’t want to talk about that. I says:
“Now you think it’s bad luck; but what did you say when I fetched in the snake-skin that I found on the top of the ridge day before yesterday? You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake-skin with my hands. Well, here’s your bad luck! We’ve raked in all this truck and eight dollars besides. I wish we could have some bad luck like this every day, Jim.”
“Never you mind, honey, never you mind. Don’t you git too peart. It’s a-comin’. Mind I tell you, it’s a-comin’.”

events.title: Huck's Prank and Jim's Snakebite
detailed_summary: Jim's premonition of bad luck materializes shortly thereafter.
Huck, intending a harmless prank, kills a rattlesnake he finds in their cave and places its coiled body at the foot of Jim's blanket.
Later that night, Huck having forgotten his prank, Jim throws himself onto the blanket, and the dead snake's mate, which had joined it, bites Jim on the heel.
Jim cries out in pain, and Huck quickly dispatches the second snake with a stick.
To treat the bite, Jim immediately begins to drink whiskey from a jug.
Following Jim's instructions for folk remedies, Huck decapitates the snake, skins its body to roast a piece for Jim to consume, and makes Jim wear the rattles on his wrist.
Overcome with guilt, Huck secretly disposes of both snakes to prevent Jim from discovering his culpability in the incident.

It did come, too. It was a Tuesday that we had that talk. Well, after dinner Friday we was laying around in the grass at the upper end of the ridge, and got out of tobacco. I went to the cavern to get some, and found a rattlesnake in there. I killed him, and curled him up on the foot of Jim’s blanket, ever so natural, thinking there’d be some fun when Jim found him there. Well, by night I forgot all about the snake, and when Jim flung himself down on the blanket while I struck a light the snake’s mate was there, and bit him.
He jumped up yelling, and the first thing the light showed was the varmint curled up and ready for another spring. I laid him out in a second with a stick, and Jim grabbed pap’s whisky-jug and begun to pour it down.
He was barefooted, and the snake bit him right on the heel. That all comes of my being such a fool as to not remember that wherever you leave a dead snake its mate always comes there and curls around it. Jim told me to chop off the snake’s head and throw it away, and then skin the body and roast a piece of it. I done it, and he eat it and said it would help cure him. He made me take off the rattles and tie them around his wrist, too. He said that that would help. Then I slid out quiet and throwed the snakes clear away amongst the bushes; for I warn’t going to let Jim find out it was all my fault, not if I could help it.

events.text_segment:
Jim sucked and sucked at the jug, and now and then he got out of his head and pitched around and yelled; but every time he come to himself he went to sucking at the jug again. His foot swelled up pretty big, and so did his leg; but by-and-by the drunk begun to come, and so I judged he was all right; but I’d druther been bit with a snake than pap’s whisky.
Jim was laid up for four days and nights. Then the swelling was all gone and he was around again. I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever take a-holt of a snake-skin again with my hands, now that I see what had come of it. Jim said he reckoned I would believe him next time. And he said that handling a snake-skin was such awful bad luck that maybe we hadn’t got to the end of it yet. He said he druther see the new moon over his left shoulder as much as a thousand times than take up a snake-skin in his hand. events.title: Catching a Gigantic Catfish
detailed_summary: As time passed and the river's water level dropped, Huck and Jim set out a large fishing hook baited with a skinned rabbit.

Upon examining the catfish's stomach, they discovered a brass button, a round, hard ball, and various other pieces of debris.
When they broke open the ball, they found a spool inside, leading Jim to speculate it had been in the fish long enough to become encrusted.
Both Huck and Jim acknowledged it was the most massive fish they had ever encountered from the Mississippi and discussed its potential value and desirability as food in the village market.

events.title: Huck's Plan for Reconnaissance in Disguise
detailed_summary: Feeling restless and bored, Huck proposes to cross the river to gather information about current events.
Jim approves of the idea, cautioning Huck to travel at night and remain vigilant.
Jim then offers a creative suggestion: Huck should disguise himself as a girl using some of the clothing they had found earlier.
They collaborate to adjust a calico gown to fit Huck, who completes the ensemble with a sun-bonnet tied under his chin, effectively obscuring his face.
Jim expresses confidence that the disguise would be convincing, even in daylight.
Huck dedicates the day to practicing feminine mannerisms, receiving guidance from Jim on how to improve his walk and to avoid instinctively reaching for his pants pocket through the dress.

That was a good notion, too. So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it. Jim hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. events.title: Huck's Arrival in Town and a Cautious Approach
detailed_summary: Under the cover of darkness, Huck paddles the canoe to the Illinois shore.
He lands the canoe a little below the ferry landing and makes his way along the riverbank towards the town.
He observes a light emanating from a small shanty that had been unoccupied for a considerable time, piquing his curiosity about its new inhabitant.
Peering through the window, Huck sees an unfamiliar woman, approximately forty years old, engaged in knitting by candlelight.
He feels a sense of relief that she is a stranger, as this lessens the chance of his voice being recognized and his true identity being compromised.
Confident that a newcomer would be well-informed about local happenings, Huck resolves to knock on the door, reminding himself to maintain his assumed persona as a girl.

I started up the Illinois shore in the canoe just after dark.
I started across to the town from a little below the ferry-landing, and the drift of the current fetched me in at the bottom of the town. I tied up and started along the bank. There was a light burning in a little shanty that hadn’t been lived in for a long time, and I wondered who had took up quarters there. I slipped up and peeped in at the window. There was a woman about forty year old in there knitting by a candle that was on a pine table. I didn’t know her face; she was a stranger, for you couldn’t start a face in that town that I didn’t know. Now this was lucky, because I was weakening; I was getting afraid I had come; people might know my voice and find me out. But if this woman had been in such a little town two days she could tell me all I wanted to know; so I knocked at the door, and made up my mind I wouldn’t forget I was a girl.

events.title: Huck's Initial Deception at the Woman's House
detailed_summary: Huck, dressed as a girl, is welcomed into a woman's home and invited to sit.
He introduces himself as Sarah Williams from Hookerville, claiming to have walked seven miles.
He states he has already eaten and is not hungry, attributing his lateness to stopping at a farm.

Huck fabricates a story about his mother being sick and destitute, and his journey to inform his Uncle Abner Moore, who supposedly lives in the town, which Huck claims to be visiting for the first time.
The woman, Judith Loftus, mentions she has only lived in the town for about two weeks and does not know Abner Moore.
She suggests Huck stay the night due to the late hour and the distance to the upper part of town, offering for him to remove his bonnet.
Huck declines, saying he will rest for a while then continue, expressing no fear of the dark.
Mrs. Loftus insists he shouldn't go alone and says her husband will accompany him, expecting him back in about an hour and a half.
She then launches into a lengthy discourse about her husband, her relatives both up and down the river, their former better circumstances, and their potential regret in moving to the current town.
Huck begins to worry that he chose the wrong person to ask for information, until her conversation shifts towards his father, Pap, and the recent murder.

She inquires about his residence, and he claims to live in Hookerville, seven miles away, explaining his fatigue from the long walk.

Mrs. Loftus, a newcomer to the town of under two weeks, doesn't know Abner Moore and suggests "Sarah" stay the night due to the distance, but Huck prefers to rest and continue, unafraid of the dark.
She proposes her husband, expected soon, could accompany him, then digresses into her family history and dissatisfaction with their move, making Huck anxious he picked the wrong informant.
Eventually, her conversation turns to Pap Finn and the murder, piquing Huck's interest.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**I done it.**  

I reckon there ain’t no use in lyin’ about it now. I done it, and I reckon I got to own up to it, even if it makes me feel lower than a snake’s belly. It all started when me and Jim was floatin’ down the river, mindin’ our own business, just tryin’ to keep out of trouble. But trouble’s got a way of findin’ a feller, whether he’s lookin’ for it or not.  

See, we come upon this little town—I ain’t gonna say the name, ‘cause it don’t matter none—and I got to thinkin’ maybe we could sneak in and get some supplies. Jim didn’t like the idea much, sayin’ it was too risky, but I was feelin’ mighty bold that day. So I went ashore, leavin’ Jim hid in the brush with the raft.  

Now, I ain’t proud of what happened next. I was walkin’ down the street, tryin’ to look like I belonged there, when I seen a feller drop his wallet. It was just layin’ there in the dirt, fat as a tick, and before I could think better of it, I scooped it up and stuffed it in my pocket. My heart was poundin’ like a drum, and I could feel the sweat runnin’ down my back.  

I told myself it weren’t stealin’, ‘cause I didn’t take it right out of his hand. But deep down, I knew better. That money weren’t mine, and I had no right to it. Still, I didn’t put it back. I just skedaddled out of there fast as I could, hopin’ nobody seen me.  

When I got back to Jim, he took one look at my face and knew somethin’ was wrong. “Huck,” he says, “what you gone and done now?” I tried to play it off like nothin’, but Jim’s got a way of seein’ right through me. Finally, I pulled out that wallet and showed him.  

Jim’s face got real serious then. “Huck,” he says, “that ain’t right. You know it ain’t.” And he was right. I did know it. But knowin’ somethin’s wrong and fixin’ it are two different things.  

I sat there for a long time, starin’ at that wallet, feelin’ sick to my stomach. I thought about the feller who dropped it—maybe he needed that money for his family, or to pay off a debt. And here I was, fixin’ to spend it on whatever I pleased. It made me feel awful small.  

Finally, I made up my mind. “Jim,” I says, “I got to take it back.” Jim nodded, lookin’ relieved. So we turned the raft around and headed back toward that town.  

It was harder goin’ back than it was leavin’. Every step felt like I was walkin’ to my own hangin’. But I knew I had to do it. When I got to where I found the wallet, I looked around for that feller, but he was long gone. So I went to the sheriff’s office and handed it over, sayin’ I found it in the street.  

The sheriff looked at me real close, like he was tryin’ to figure out if I was lyin’. “You’re a honest boy,” he says finally. “Most folks would’ve kept it.”  

That made me feel worse, ‘cause I *had* kept it—for a little while, anyway. But I didn’t say nothin’. I just nodded and got out of there fast as I could.  

When I got back to Jim, I felt lighter, like a weight had been lifted off my chest. Jim didn’t say much, just clapped me on the shoulder and said, “You done good, Huck.”  

I reckon that’s the end of it. But I learned somethin’ important that day—stealin’ ain’t just about the act itself. It’s about how it sits in your soul afterward. And I don’t ever want to feel that way again.  

So yeah—I done it. But I fixed it too. And that’s gotta count for somethin’.

events.title: Imminent Danger: Jim's Hideout on Jackson's Island Revealed
detailed_summary: Mrs. Loftus responds that many people still believe Jim committed the murder and expect his capture soon.
When Huck asks if they are still actively searching for Jim, Mrs. Loftus, calling Huck "innocent," points out that a $300 reward is a significant incentive.
She confides that she personally believes Jim is not far away, a sentiment she hasn't widely shared.
She recounts a recent conversation with elderly neighbors who live in a log shanty, who mentioned that Jackson's Island is rarely visited and uninhabited.
This information, coupled with her memory of seeing smoke near the head of the island a day or two earlier, led her to suspect Jim might be hiding there.
She decided the island was worth investigating.
Although she hasn't seen smoke since and speculates Jim might have departed if it was him, she informed her husband about her suspicions.
Her husband, who had been upriver, returned that day, and she told him about the smoke just two hours prior to Huck's arrival; he and another man intend to search the island.
