This was the meanest, orneriest spirit that ever walked the earth, with eyes like fire-coals and a voice that rumbled like thunder down a hollow log. Jim said it come creepin’ up on him in the dead of night, rustlin’ through the cane-brake like a thousand snakes, and when it got close, why, the air turned so cold it near froze his bones solid.

He claimed that ghost had followed him clear across the river, floatin’ just above the water without makin’ so much as a ripple, and when Jim tried to shake it by duckin’ into the woods, why, that haint just laughed—a sound like nails scrapin’ on a slate—and kept right on his trail. Jim said he run till his legs give out, and still that thing kept comin’, whisperin’ his name in a voice that wasn’t human at all. 

Now, I reckon Jim was stretchin’ the truth some, seein’ as how he’s partial to a good tale, but I didn’t let on. He was shook up enough without me callin’ him a liar. So I just nodded along and said, “That’s powerful strange, Jim. What’d you do then?” 

Well, Jim said he finally dropped to his knees and commenced to prayin’ like he never prayed before, and that’s when the ghost let out a howl so awful it made the hair stand up on the back of his neck. Then—just like that—it was gone. Vanished clean away, leavin’ nothin’ but the smell of burnt sulfur and a chill in the air that took till sunup to warm out of him. 

I asked him if he reckoned it might’ve been Pap’s ghost, seein’ as how Pap had passed recent, but Jim shook his head solemn-like and said, “No, Huck, this here was somethin’ older. Somethin’ that’s been walkin’ this land long before white men or black men set foot on it.” 

Well, that sent a shiver down my spine, I don’t mind sayin’. Jim’s stories always got a way of makin’ you feel like there’s eyes watchin’ you from the dark, even when you know there ain’t. So we sat there by the fire a spell longer, not sayin’ much, just listenin’ to the night sounds and feelin’ mighty small under all them stars. 

After a while, Jim sighed and said, “Reckon we best turn in, Huck. Dawn comes early.” And I didn’t argue none. Some tales are best left in the dark.

*"But that was enough. It was according to the old saying, 'Give a nigger an inch and he'll take an ell.' Thinks I, this is what comes of my not thinking. Here was this nigger, which I had as good as helped to run away, coming right out flat-footed and saying he would steal his children—children that belonged to a man I didn’t even know; a man that hadn’t ever done me no harm.*  

*I was sorry to hear Jim say that, it was such a lowering of him. My conscience got to stirring me up hotter than ever, until at last I says to it, 'Let up on me—it ain’t too late yet—I’ll paddle ashore at the first light and tell.' I felt easy and happy and light as a feather right off. All my troubles was gone. I went to looking out sharp for a light, and sort of singing to myself. By and by one showed. Jim sings out:*  

*'We’s safe, Huck, we’s safe! Jump up and crack yo’ heels! Dat’s de good ole Cairo at las’, I jis knows it!'*  

*I says:*  

*'I’ll take the canoe and go and see, Jim. It mightn’t be, you know.'*  

*He jumped and got the canoe ready, and put his old coat in the bottom for me to set on, and give me the paddle; and as I shoved off, he says:*  

*'Pooty soon I’ll be a-shout’n’ for joy, en I’ll say, it’s all on accounts o’ Huck; I’s a free man, en I couldn’t ever ben free ef it hadn’t ben for Huck; Huck done it. Jim won’t ever forgit you, Huck; you’s de bes’ fren’ Jim’s ever had; en you’s de only fren’ ole Jim’s got now.'*  

*I was paddling off, all in a sweat to tell on him; but when he says this, it seemed to kind of take the tuck all out of me. I went along slow then, and I warn’t right down certain whether I was glad I started or whether I warn’t. When I was fifty yards off, Jim says:*  

*'Dah you goes, de ole true Huck; de on’y white genlman dat ever kep’ his promise to ole Jim.'*  

*Well, I just felt sick. But I says, I got to do it—I can’t get out of it. Right then along comes a skiff with two men in it with guns, and they stopped and I stopped. One of them says:*  

*'What’s that yonder?'*  

*'A piece of a raft,' I says.*  

*'Do you belong on it?'*  

*'Yes, sir.'*  

*'Any men on it?'*  

*'Only one, sir.'*  

*'Well, there’s five niggers run off to-night up yonder, above the head of the bend. Is your man white or black?'*  

*I didn’t answer up prompt. I tried to, but the words wouldn’t come. I tried for a second or two to brace up and out with it, but I warn’t man enough—hadn’t the spunk of a rabbit. I see I was weakening; so I just give up trying, and up and says:*  

*'He’s white.'*  

*'I reckon we’ll go and see for ourselves.'*  

*'I wish you would,' says I, 'because it’s pap that’s there, and maybe you’d help me tow the raft ashore where the light is. He’s sick—and so is mam and Mary Ann.'*  

*'Oh, the devil! we’re in a hurry, boy. But I s’pose we’ve got to. Come, buckle to your paddle, and let’s get along.'*  

*I buckled to my paddle and they laid to their oars. When we had made a stroke or two, I says:*  

*'Pap’ll be mighty much obleeged to you, I can tell you. Everybody goes away when I want them to help me tow the raft ashore, and I can’t do it by myself.'*  

*'Well, that’s infernal mean. Odd, too. Say, boy, what’s the matter with your father?'*  

*'It’s the—a—the—well, it ain’t anything much.'*  

*They stopped pulling. It warn’t but a mighty little ways to the raft now. One says:*  

*'Boy, that’s a lie. What is the matter with your pap? Answer up square now, or it’ll be the worse for you.'*  

*'I will, sir, I will, honest—but don’t leave us, please. It’s the—the—gentlemen, if you’ll only pull ahead, and let me heave you the headline, you won’t have to come a-near the raft—please do.'*  

*'Set her back, John, set her back!' says one. They backed water. 'Keep away, boy—keep to looard. Confound it, I just expect the wind has blowed it to us. Your pap’s got the small-pox, and you know it precious well. Why didn’t you come out and say so? Do you want to spread it all over?'*  

*'Well,' says I, a-blubbering, 'I’ve told everybody before, and they just went away and left us.'*  

*'Poor devil, there’s something in that. We are right down sorry for you, but we—well, hang it, we don’t want the small-pox, you see. Look here, I’ll tell you what to do. Don’t you try to land by yourself, or you’ll smash everything to pieces. You float along down about twenty miles, and you’ll come to a town on the left-hand side of the river. It will be long after sun-up then, and when you ask for help you tell them your folks are all down with chills and fever. Don’t you be a fool again, and let people guess what is the matter. Now we’re trying to do you a kindness; so you just put twenty miles between us, that’s a good boy. It wouldn’t do any good to land yonder where the light is—it’s only a wood-yard. Say, I reckon your father’s poor, and I’m bound to say he’s in pretty hard luck. Here, I’ll put a twenty-dollar gold piece on this board, and you get it when it floats by. I feel mighty mean to leave you; but my kingdom! it won’t do to fool with small-pox, don’t you see?'*  

*'Hold on, Parker,' says the other man, 'here’s a twenty to put on the board for me. Good-by, boy; you do as Mr. Parker told you, and you’ll be all right.'*  

*'That’s so, my boy—good-by, good-by. If you see any runaway niggers you get help and nab them, and you can make some money by it.'*  

*'Good-by, sir,' says I; 'I won’t let no runaway niggers get by me if I can help it.'*  

*They went off and I got aboard the raft, feeling bad and low, because I knowed very well I had done wrong, and I see it warn’t no use for me to try to learn to do right; a body that don’t get started right when he’s little ain’t got no show—when the pinch comes there ain’t nothing to back him up and keep him to his work, and so he gets beat. Then I thought a minute, and says to myself, hold on; s’pose you’d a done right and give Jim up, would you felt better than what you do now? No, says I, I’d feel bad—I’d feel just the same way I do now. Well, then, says I, what’s the use you learning to do right when it’s troublesome to do right and ain’t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the same? I was stuck. I couldn’t answer that. So I reckoned I wouldn’t bother no more about it, but after this always do whichever come handiest at the time.*  

*I went into the wigwam; Jim warn’t there. I looked all around; he warn’t anywhere. I says:*  

*'Jim!'*  

*'Here I is, Huck. Is dey out o’ sight yit? Don’t talk loud.'*  

*He was in the river under the stern oar, with just his nose out. I told him they was out of sight, so he come aboard. He says:*  

*'I was a-listenin’ to all de talk, en I slips into de river en was gwyne to shove for sho’ if dey come aboard. Den I was gwyne to swim to de raf’ agin when dey was gone. But lawsy, how you did fool ’em, Huck! Dat wuz de smartes’ dodge! I tell you, chile, I ’spec it save’ ole Jim—ole Jim ain’t going to forgit you for dat, honey.'*  

*Then we talked about the money. It was a pretty good raise—twenty dollars apiece. Jim said we could take deck passage on a steamboat now, and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free States. He said twenty mile more warn’t far for the raft to go, but he wished we was already there.*  

*Towards daybreak we tied up, and Jim was mighty particular about hiding the raft good. Then he worked all day fixing things in bundles, and getting all ready to quit rafting.*  

*That night about ten we hove in sight of the lights of a town away down in a left-hand bend.*  

*I went off in the canoe to ask about it. Pretty soon I found a man out in the river with a skiff, setting a trot-line. I ranged up and says:*  

*'Mister, is that town Cairo?'*  

*'Cairo? No. You must be a blame’ fool.'*  

*'What town is it, mister?'*  

*'If you want to know, go and find out. If you stay here botherin’ around me for about a half a minute longer you’ll get something you won’t want.'*  

*I paddled to the raft. Jim was awful disappointed, but I said never mind, Cairo would be the next place, I reckoned.*  

*We passed another town before daylight, and I was going out again; but it was high ground, so I didn’t go. No high ground about Cairo, Jim said. I had forgot it. We laid up for the day on a towhead tolerable close to the left-hand bank. I begun to suspicion something. So did Jim. I says:*  

*'Maybe we went by Cairo in the fog that night.'*  

*He says:*  

*'Doan’ le’s talk about it, Huck. Po’ niggers can’t have no luck. I awluz ’spected dat rattlesnake-skin warn’t done wid its work.'*  

*'I wish I’d never seen that snake-skin, Jim—I do wish I’d never laid eyes on it.'*  

*'It ain’t yo’ fault, Huck; you didn’t know. Don’t you blame yo’self ’bout it.'*  

*When it was daylight, here was the clear Ohio water inshore, sure enough, and outside was the old regular Muddy! So it was all up with Cairo.*  

*We talked it all over. It wouldn’t do to take to the shore; we couldn’t take the raft up the stream, of course. There warn’t no way but to wait for dark, and start back in the canoe and take the chances. So we slept all day amongst the cottonwood thicket, so as to be fresh for the work, and when we went back to the raft about dark the canoe was gone!*  

*We didn’t say a word for a good while. There warn’t anything to say. We both knowed well enough it was some more work of the rattlesnake-skin; so what was the use to talk about it? It would only look like we was finding fault, and that would be bound to fetch more bad luck—and keep on fetching it, too, till we knowed enough to keep still.*  

*By and by we talked about what we better do, and found there warn’t no way but just to go along down with the raft till we got a chance to buy a canoe to go back in. We warn’t going to borrow it when there warn’t anybody around, the way pap would do, for that might set folks after us.*  

*So we shoved out after dark on the raft.*  

*Anybody that don’t believe yet that it’s foolishness to handle a snake-skin, after all that that snake-skin done for us, will believe it now if they read on and see what more it done for us.*

events.title: Journeying Towards Cairo and Formulating a Plan
detailed_summary: Huck and Jim observe an impressively large raft, noting its size, multiple wigwams, and the numerous crew it likely carried, which made being a raftsman on such a vessel seem significant.
They drift down a large bend in the river as the night becomes cloudy and hot, with the wide river bordered by continuous, dark timber.
They discuss their anxiety about how they will recognize Cairo, particularly since Huck heard it was small and might not be lit up.
Jim suggests that the confluence of the two large rivers at Cairo would be a clear indicator.
Huck raises the concern that they might misinterpret the joining of the rivers as merely passing the end of an island and re-entering the same river, a thought that unsettles both him and Jim.

Faced with this uncertainty, Huck proposes that when they see the first light, he will paddle ashore to inquire about the distance to Cairo, inventing a story about his inexperienced father following on a trading-scow.
Jim approves of this plan, and they decide to smoke and wait for an opportunity.

We slept most all day, and started out at night, a little ways behind a monstrous long raft that was as long going by as a procession. She had four long sweeps at each end, so we judged she carried as many as thirty men, likely. She had five big wigwams aboard, wide apart, and an open camp fire in the middle, and a tall flag-pole at each end. There was a power of style about her. It amounted to something being a raftsman on such a craft as that.
We went drifting down into a big bend, and the night clouded up and got hot. The river was very wide, and was walled with solid timber on both sides; you couldn’t see a break in it hardly ever, or a light. We talked about Cairo, and wondered whether we would know it when we got to it. I said likely we wouldn’t, because I had heard say there warn’t but about a dozen houses there, and if they didn’t happen to have them lit up, how was we going to know we was passing a town? Jim said if the two big rivers joined together there, that would show. But I said maybe we might think we was passing the foot of an island and coming into the same old river again. That disturbed Jim—and me too. So the question was, what to do? I said, paddle ashore the first time a light showed, and tell them pap was behind, coming along with a trading-scow, and was a green hand at the business, and wanted to know how far it was to Cairo. Jim thought it was a good idea, so we took a smoke on it and waited.

We slept most all day, and started out at night, a little ways behind a monstrous long raft that was as long going by as a procession. The moon was high, casting a silvery glow over the river, and the air was thick with the sounds of frogs and crickets. Jim and I kept our distance, letting the current carry us slow and steady.

events.title: Jim's Eagerness for Freedom and Huck's Moral Torment
detailed_summary: With nothing else to do, they focused on vigilantly watching for Cairo, determined not to miss it.
Jim expresses his intense anticipation, stating he'll be a free man upon seeing Cairo but will be back in slave country if he misses it, frequently jumping up and mistakenly identifying lights.
Jim's excitement and nearness to freedom make him feel tremulous and feverish, which in turn deeply agitates Huck.
Huck experiences a profound crisis of conscience, realizing the full weight of his actions in helping Jim escape and feeling responsible.
His conscience plagues him, reminding him of Miss Watson's kindnesses—her attempts to educate him and teach him manners—and making him feel he has treated her poorly.
Huck feels wretched and miserable, pacing the raft in distress, mirrored by Jim's own restless anticipation.

While Huck is lost in his internal turmoil, Jim aloud details his plans for freedom: first, he would save money diligently, then buy his wife's freedom, and subsequently, they would work together to purchase their two children. If their master refused to sell the children, Jim declared he would enlist an abolitionist to steal them.

Huck is profoundly shocked by Jim's statement about stealing his children, viewing it as an unacceptable transgression and a direct result of his own complicity in Jim's escape, implicating him in a crime against an unknown man who had done him no personal harm.

There warn’t nothing to do now but to look out sharp for the town, and not pass it without seeing it. He said he’d be mighty sure to see it, because he’d be a free man the minute he seen it, but if he missed it he’d be in a slave country again and no more show for freedom. Every little while he jumps up and says:
“Dah she is?”
But it warn’t. It was Jack-o’-lanterns, or lightning bugs; so he set down again, and went to watching, same as before. Jim said it made him all over trembly and feverish to be so close to freedom. Well, I can tell you it made me all over trembly and feverish, too, to hear him, because I begun to get it through my head that he was most free—and who was to blame for it? Why, me. I couldn’t get that out of my conscience, no how nor no way. It got to troubling me so I couldn’t rest; I couldn’t stay still in one place. It hadn’t ever come home to me before, what this thing was that I was doing. But now it did; and it stayed with me, and scorched me more and more. I tried to make out to myself that I warn’t to blame, because I didn’t run Jim off from his rightful owner; but it warn’t no use, conscience up and says, every time, “But you knowed he was running for his freedom, and you could a paddled ashore and told somebody.” That was so—I couldn’t get around that noway. That was where it pinched. Conscience says to me, “What had poor Miss Watson done to you that you could see her nigger go off right under your eyes and never say one single word? What did that poor old woman do to you that you could treat her so mean? Why, she tried to learn you your book, she tried to learn you your manners, she tried to be good to you every way she knowed how. That’s what she done.”
I got to feeling so mean and so miserable I most wished I was dead. I fidgeted up and down the raft, abusing myself to myself, and Jim was fidgeting up and down past me. We neither of us could keep still. Every time he danced around and says, “Dah’s Cairo!” it went through me like a shot, and I thought if it was Cairo I reckoned I would die of miserableness.
Jim talked out loud all the time while I was talking to myself. We glided along, keeping a sharp eye out for any sign of the town. The river was wide and dark, with the moonlight dancing on the ripples like silver coins. Jim was at the stern, steering careful-like, while I sat up front, squinting into the shadows. The air was thick with the smell of wet earth and old river water, and now and then a bullfrog would croak out a lonely note from the bank.

“You reckon we passed it?” Jim asked after a spell, his voice low so as not to carry over the water.

“I dunno,” I said, scratching my head. “But we ain’t seen no lights nor heard no dogs barkin’. A town’s got to have dogs.”

Jim nodded, his face solemn in the pale light. “Might be we come on it sudden-like. Best keep watch.”

So we did, both of us peering into the gloom, listening hard for any sound that might mean folks was near. The current was strong, and the raft moved steady, slipping past the banks like a ghost. Every now and then, a fish would jump, making a little splash that set my heart to pounding, thinking maybe it was a paddle dipping into the water.

Then, just when I was starting to think we’d missed the place altogether, I caught sight of a dim glow through the trees. “Jim!” I whispered sharp. “Yonder—see that light?”

Jim turned his head slow, not wanting to make no sudden moves. “I sees it,” he said. “Ain’t much, but it’s somethin’.”

We eased the raft closer to the bank, real quiet, till we could make out the shapes of buildings—just dark lumps against the sky, with that one yellow light flickering in a window. It warn’t much of a town, but it was a town all the same.

“What you reckon we oughta do?” Jim asked.

I studied on it a minute. “Well, we can’t go traipsin’ in there this time o’ night. Somebody’s bound to see us and start askin’ questions we ain’t got answers for.”

Jim nodded again. “We could tie up here, wait for daylight.”

That seemed the safest bet. So we found a likely spot where the trees hung low over the water, and we tied the raft up good and snug. Then we settled down to wait, listening to the night sounds and watching that lone light in the distance. It was awful lonesome, but it beat being caught.

After a while, Jim said, “Huck, you ever think ‘bout what’s waitin’ for us downriver?”

I hadn’t, much. The river was just the river, carrying us wherever it pleased. But now that he mentioned it, I got to wondering. “Reckon there’s good folks and bad folks everywhere,” I said at last. “We just got to be careful which is which.”

Jim didn’t say nothing to that, but I could tell he was thinking hard. Maybe about freedom, maybe about what lay ahead. Me, I was just glad to be away from Pap and all the trouble back home. The river was our road now, and come morning, we’d see where it led us next.

The light in the window flickered once, then went out, leaving the town in darkness. Somewhere far off, a dog barked, and the sound sent a shiver down my spine. But the raft was steady beneath us, and the river murmured soft and low, like it was telling us to sleep. So we did, or tried to, with one eye open and our ears tuned sharp for trouble.

events.title: Huck's Crisis of Conscience and Deceptive Encounter
detailed_summary: Huck feels that Jim's stated intention to steal his children is a moral degradation, further intensifying his own guilt.
His conscience troubles him so severely that he resolves to betray Jim by paddling ashore at the next opportunity to report him, a decision that brings him immediate relief and a sense of lightness.
As Huck prepares the canoe, Jim, unaware of Huck's intentions, expresses heartfelt gratitude, calling Huck his best and only friend and attributing his imminent freedom entirely to Huck's help.
Jim's sincere words deeply move Huck, causing him to waver in his resolve to turn Jim in.
Suddenly, a skiff with two armed men appears; they are searching for five escaped slaves and question Huck about the person on his raft.
Huck struggles to speak but eventually lies, claiming the occupant is his white father.
To further deter the men from investigating, Huck implies his family on the raft is suffering from a contagious illness, eventually hinting at smallpox when pressed for details.

The men, alarmed by the mention of smallpox, quickly retreat, offering Huck money (two twenty-dollar gold pieces) out of pity and advising him to float twenty miles further to a town, where he should claim his family has chills and fever. They also instruct him to report any runaway slaves he might encounter.

I was sorry to hear Jim say that, it was such a lowering of him. My conscience got to stirring me up hotter than ever, until at last I says to it, “Let up on me—it ain’t too late yet—I’ll paddle ashore at the first light and tell.” I felt easy and happy and light as a feather right off. All my troubles was gone. I went to looking out sharp for a light, and sort of singing to myself. By-and-by one showed. Jim sings out:
“We’s safe, Huck, we’s safe! Jump up and crack yo’ heels! Dat’s de good ole Cairo at las’, I jis knows it!”
I says:
“I’ll take the canoe and go and see, Jim. It mightn’t be, you know.”
He jumped and got the canoe ready, and put his old coat in the bottom for me to set on, and give me the paddle; and as I shoved off, he says:
“Pooty soon I’ll be a-shout’n’ for joy, en I’ll say, it’s all on accounts o’ Huck; I’s a free man, en I couldn’t ever ben free ef it hadn’ ben for Huck; Huck done it. Jim won’t ever forgit you, Huck; you’s de bes’ fren’ Jim’s ever had; en you’s de only fren’ ole Jim’s got now.”
I was paddling off, all in a sweat to tell on him; but when he says this, it seemed to kind of take the tuck all out of me. I went along slow then, and I warn’t right down certain whether I was glad I started or whether I warn’t. When I was fifty yards off, Jim says:
“Dah you goes, de ole true Huck; de on’y white genlman dat ever kep’ his promise to ole Jim.”
Well, I just felt sick. But I says, I got to do it—I can’t get out of it. Right then along comes a skiff with two men in it with guns, and they stopped and I stopped. One of them says:
“What’s that yonder?”
“A piece of a raft,” I says.
“Do you belong on it?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Any men on it?”
“Only one, sir.”
“Well, there’s five niggers run off to-night up yonder, above the head of the bend. Is your man white or black?”
I didn’t answer up prompt. I tried to, but the words wouldn’t come. I tried for a second or two to brace up and out with it, but I warn’t man enough—hadn’t the spunk of a rabbit. I see I was weakening; so I just give up trying, and up and says:
“He’s white.”
“I reckon we’ll go and see for ourselves.”
“I wish you would,” says I, “because it’s pap that’s there, and maybe you’d help me tow the raft ashore where the light is. He’s sick—and so is mam and Mary Ann.”
“Oh, the devil! we’re in a hurry, boy. But I s’pose we’ve got to. Come, buckle to your paddle, and let’s get along.”
I buckled to my paddle and they laid to their oars. When we had made a stroke or two, I says:
“Pap’ll be mighty much obleeged to you, I can tell you. Everybody goes away when I want them to help me tow the raft ashore, and I can’t do it by myself.”
“Well, that’s infernal mean. Odd, too. Say, boy, what’s the matter with your father?”
“It’s the—a—the—well, it ain’t anything much.”
They stopped pulling. It warn’t but a mighty little ways to the raft now. One says:
“Boy, that’s a lie. What is the matter with your pap? Answer up square now, and it’ll be the better for you.”
“I will, sir, I will, honest—but don’t leave us, please. It’s the—the—gentlemen, if you’ll only pull ahead, and let me heave you the headline, you won’t have to come a-near the raft—please do.”
“Set her back, John, set her back!” says one. They backed water. “Keep away, boy—keep to looard. Confound it, I just expect the wind has blowed it to us. Your pap’s got the small-pox, and you know it precious well. Why didn’t you come out and say so? Do you want to spread it all over?”
“Well,” says I, a-blubbering, “I’ve told everybody before, and they just went away and left us.”
“Poor devil, there’s something in that. We are right down sorry for you, but we—well, hang it, we don’t want the small-pox, you see. Look here, I’ll tell you what to do. Don’t you try to land by yourself, or you’ll smash everything to pieces. You float along down about twenty miles, and you’ll come to a town on the left-hand side of the river. It will be long after sun-up then, and when you ask for help you tell them your folks are all down with chills and fever. Don’t be a fool again, and let people guess what is the matter. Now we’re trying to do you a kindness; so you just put twenty miles between us, that’s a good boy. It wouldn’t do any good to land yonder where the light is—it’s only a wood-yard. Say, I reckon your father’s poor, and I’m bound to say he’s in pretty hard luck. Here, I’ll put a twenty-dollar gold piece on this board, and you get it when it floats by. I feel mighty mean to leave you; but my kingdom! it won’t do to fool with small-pox, don’t you see?”
“Hold on, Parker,” says the other man, “here’s a twenty to put on the board for me. Good-bye, boy; you do as Mr. Parker told you, and you’ll be all right.”
“That’s so, my boy—good-bye, good-bye. If you see any runaway niggers you get help and nab them, and you can make some money by it.”

He reflects on his moral failings, concluding that he is inherently flawed and that attempting to 'do right' according to societal standards is futile for him, as it brings no more peace than doing 'wrong'.

He reasons that if doing right is difficult and yields the same miserable feeling as doing wrong (which is easier), then there's no point in striving for it, deciding instead to always do what is most convenient at the moment.
Huck finds Jim, who had hidden in the river during the encounter, having overheard everything.
Jim is overjoyed and immensely impressed by Huck's quick-witted deception, praising it as a clever trick that saved him.
They discuss the forty dollars they received, with Jim excitedly noting it's enough to secure deck passage on a steamboat to the free states.
Jim expresses his eagerness to reach their destination, though he acknowledges the raft has only twenty more miles to go, and spends the following day preparing their belongings to leave the raft.

events.title: Missed Opportunity at Cairo and Compounding Misfortunes
detailed_summary: Around ten o'clock that night, they spot the lights of a town.
Huck takes the canoe to investigate if it is Cairo, but is met with hostility by a man on a skiff who curtly denies it is Cairo and threatens him.
Jim is greatly disappointed by the news, but Huck tries to reassure him that Cairo will be the next town.
They pass another town before daylight, but Huck doesn't investigate because it's on high ground, which Jim had said Cairo was not.
A growing suspicion arises in both Huck and Jim that they might have unknowingly passed Cairo during a foggy night.
Jim attributes their misfortune to the lingering bad luck from the rattlesnake skin Huck had previously handled.
The following morning, the sight of the clear Ohio River water merging with the muddy Mississippi confirms their fears: they have indeed passed Cairo.
They discuss their predicament and decide their only option is to wait for dark and attempt to paddle back upriver in the canoe.
After resting all day to prepare for the strenuous journey, they return to the raft only to find that their canoe has disappeared.
They silently accept this new setback, again attributing it to the rattlesnake skin's curse, and conclude that complaining would only bring more bad luck.
Their only remaining option is to continue downriver on the raft until they can find an opportunity to purchase another canoe.
They decide against stealing a canoe, as Huck's father might have done, to avoid pursuit, and set off on the raft after dark.

That night about ten we hove in sight of the lights of a town away down in a left-hand bend.
I went off in the canoe to ask about it. Pretty soon I found a man out in the river with a skiff, setting a trot-line. I ranged up and says:
“Mister, is that town Cairo?”
“Cairo? no. You must be a blame’ fool.”
“What town is it, mister?”
“If you want to know, go and find out. If you stay here botherin’ around me for about a half a minute longer you’ll get something you won’t want.”
I paddled to the raft. Jim was awful disappointed, but I said never mind, Cairo would be the next place, I reckoned.
We passed another town before daylight, and I was going out again; but it was high ground, so I didn’t go. No high ground about Cairo, Jim said. I had forgot it. We laid up for the day on a tow-head tolerable close to the left-hand bank. I begun to suspicion something. So did Jim. I says:
“Maybe we went by Cairo in the fog that night.”
He says:
“Doan’ le’s talk about it, Huck. Po’ niggers can’t have no luck. I awluz ’spected dat rattlesnake-skin warn’t done wid its work.”
“I wish I’d never seen that snake-skin, Jim—I do wish I’d never laid eyes on it.”
“It ain’t yo’ fault, Huck; you didn’ know. Don’t you blame yo’self ’bout it.”
When it was daylight, here was the clear Ohio water inshore, sure enough, and outside was the old regular Muddy! So it was all up with Cairo.
We talked it all over. It wouldn’t do to take to the shore; we couldn’t take the raft up the stream, of course. There warn’t no way but to wait for dark, and start back in the canoe and take the chances. So we slept all day amongst the cottonwood thicket, so as to be fresh for the work, and when we went back to the raft about dark the canoe was gone!
We didn’t say a word for a good while. There warn’t anything to say. We both knowed well enough it was some more work of the rattlesnake-skin; so what was the use to talk about it? It would only look like we was finding fault, and that would be bound to fetch more bad luck—and keep on fetching it, too, till we knowed enough to keep still.
By-and-by we talked about what we better do, and found there warn’t no way but just to go along down with the raft till we got a chance to buy a canoe to go back in. We warn’t going to borrow it when there warn’t anybody around, the way pap would do, for that might set people after us.
So we shoved out after dark on the raft.

events.title: The Steamboat Collision and Destruction of the Raft
detailed_summary: Huck emphasizes the persistent bad luck he attributes to the snakeskin, suggesting that subsequent events will further prove its malevolent influence.
They drift for over three hours, unable to find any rafts moored ashore from which they might buy a canoe.
The night becomes gray and thick with mist, significantly impairing visibility, making it difficult to discern the river's shape or see any distance.
Late in the still night, a steamboat approaches from upriver.
Although they light their lantern, expecting the steamboat to see them, it continues directly towards them; Huck notes that upstream boats in such conditions often power straight up the channel.
They hear the steamboat's engine pounding but only see it clearly when it is very close, aiming directly for their raft.
Huck recalls that steamboats sometimes intentionally come dangerously close to rafts for sport.
This steamboat, however, makes no attempt to steer away and rapidly bears down on them, appearing as a massive, dark entity with glowing furnace doors.

Amidst shouts from the steamboat, the ringing of engine bells, cursing, and the hiss of steam, the steamboat crashes directly through the raft, forcing Huck and Jim to leap into the river on opposite sides to escape being crushed.

Things had been bad enough already—what with the storm, the wrecked raft, and us getting separated—but that cursed snake-skin wasn’t done with its mischief. Jim had warned me from the start, saying it was the worst kind of luck to touch one, and I reckon he was right.  

After we got back together and patched up the raft best we could, we figured our troubles were behind us. But no sooner had we set off again than we heard a steamboat coming downriver, churning up the water like Judgment Day was at hand. Before we could steer clear, that boat plowed right over us, splitting the raft clean in two and sending us flying into the dark.  

I came up sputtering and hollering for Jim, but there weren’t no answer. I swam around in that black water till my arms near gave out, and just when I was about to give up hope, I caught hold of a piece of driftwood and clung on for dear life. Come daylight, I found myself washed up on shore, alone and shivering, with nothing but the clothes on my back and that awful snake-skin’s curse still hanging over me.  

Jim turned up later, thank the Lord, but he was mighty solemn about it. “Didn’t I tell you, Huck?” he said. “Dat snake-skin’s got de devil in it.” And after all that happened, I couldn’t argue with him. events.title: Separation from Jim and Arrival at a Hostile Shore
detailed_summary: Huck dives deep into the river to avoid the steamboat's massive paddle wheel, staying submerged for what felt like a minute and a half.
When he surfaces, breathless, he sees the steamboat continuing upriver, its crew apparently unconcerned about the raft or its occupants.
He calls out for Jim multiple times but receives no response, leading him to fear for Jim's safety.
Grabbing onto a loose plank, Huck begins to swim towards the shore, noticing that the current is carrying him towards the left bank.
He endures a long, arduous swim across a wide section of the river, eventually making a safe landing on the bank.
Disoriented in the darkness, he navigates rough terrain for about a quarter of a mile before unexpectedly coming across a large, old-fashioned double log house.
As Huck considers quickly passing by the house, a large group of dogs rushes out, barking and howling aggressively, effectively trapping him and preventing him from moving any further.

events.text_segment:
I dived—and I aimed to find the bottom, too, for a thirty-foot wheel had got to go over me, and I wanted it to have plenty of room. I could always stay under water a minute; this time I reckon I stayed under a minute and a half. Then I bounced for the top in a hurry, for I was nearly busting. I popped out to my armpits and blowed the water out of my nose, and puffed a bit. Of course there was a booming current; and of course that boat started her engines again ten seconds after she stopped them, for they never cared much for raftsmen; so now she was churning along up the river, out of sight in the thick weather, though I could hear her.
I sung out for Jim about a dozen times, but I didn’t get any answer; so I grabbed a plank that touched me while I was “treading water,” and struck out for shore, shoving it ahead of me. But I made out to see that the drift of the current was towards the left-hand shore, which meant that I was in a crossing; so I changed off and went that way.
It was one of these long, slanting, two-mile crossings; so I was a good long time in getting over. I made a safe landing, and clumb up the bank. I couldn’t see but a little ways, but I went poking along over rough ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I run across a big old-fashioned double log-house before I noticed it. I was going to rush by and get away, but a lot of dogs jumped out and went to howling and barking at me, and I knowed better than to move another peg.

I dived—and I aimed to find the bottom, too, for a thirty-foot wheel had got to go over me, and I wanted it to have plenty of room. The river was mighty deep just there, and the current strong as it sucked me down. I held my breath till my lungs near burst, kicking hard to get clear of that churning wheel. The water roared in my ears like a thousand steamboats, and I could feel the pull of the paddle as it churned closer.  

For a second, I thought I was done for. Then my fingers scraped mud—the river bottom at last. I clawed at it, dragging myself deeper, praying the wheel would pass over without snatching me up. The whole Mississippi seemed to be bearing down on me, heavy and dark.  

Then—just like that—the worst of the pull was gone. The wheel had rolled over, leaving me in the swirling quiet below. I kicked off the bottom, shooting up toward the light, my chest burning for air. When I broke the surface, gasping, the steamboat was already yards downstream, its wake slapping against the banks.  

I swam for the nearest shore, my arms shaking, and hauled myself onto the mud like a half-drowned cat. Lying there, panting, I reckoned I’d had enough of steamboats and their wheels to last me a lifetime. One thing was sure—Huck Finn wasn’t meant to be ground up like cornmeal. I’d had my close call, and next time, I’d keep clear of trouble—or at least try to.

events.title: Cautious Interrogation at a Stranger's House
detailed_summary: Huck, identifying himself as George Jackson, is questioned from within a darkened house by a man whose dogs are preventing Huck's passage.
Huck explains his predicament, stating he fell overboard from a steamboat and means no harm.
The man remains cautious, issuing orders for careful handling of lights and summoning Bob and Tom with firearms.
He interrogates Huck about any potential companions and specifically asks if Huck knows the 'Shepherdsons,' a name Huck professes to have never heard.
Huck is given strict instructions to approach the house very slowly, push the door open himself, and is warned that any companion revealing themselves will be shot.
With his heart pounding and the house dogs silently trailing him, Huck complies, reaches the door, and pushes it open slightly upon command.
He is then told to insert his head, a moment during which he fears potential harm.

events.text_segment:
In about a minute somebody spoke out of a window without putting his head out, and says:
“Be done, boys! Who’s there?”
I says:
“It’s me.”
“Who’s me?”
“George Jackson, sir.”
“What do you want?”
“I don’t want nothing, sir. I only want to go along by, but the dogs won’t let me.”
“What are you prowling around here this time of night for—hey?”
“I warn’t prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.”
“Oh, you did, did you? Strike a light there, somebody. What did you say your name was?”
“George Jackson, sir. I’m only a boy.”
“Look here, if you’re telling the truth you needn’t be afraid—nobody’ll hurt you. But don’t try to budge; stand right where you are. Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns. George Jackson, is there anybody with you?”
“No, sir, nobody.”
I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light. The man sung out:
“Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool—ain’t you got any sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door. Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places.”
“All ready.”
“Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
“No, sir; I never heard of them.”
“Well, that may be so, and it mayn’t. Now, all ready. Step forward, George Jackson. And mind, don’t you hurry—come mighty slow. If there’s anybody with you, let him keep back—if he shows himself he’ll be shot. Come along now. Come slow; push the door open yourself—just enough to squeeze in, d’ you hear?”
I didn’t hurry; I couldn’t if I’d a wanted to. I took one slow step at a time and there warn’t a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart. The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me. When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting. I put my hand on the door and pushed it a little and a little more till somebody said, “There, that’s enough—put your head in.” I done it, but I judged they would take it off.

detailed_summary: Upon entering, Huck finds himself facing three armed men, an elderly lady, and two younger women, all intently observing him.
The eldest man, after a brief assessment, declares that Huck is not a Shepherdson and permits him to come fully inside.
The door is immediately secured behind him, and the entire group moves into a large parlor, situated away from the range of the front windows.
Following a closer examination, the family members collectively conclude that Huck bears no resemblance to any Shepherdson.
The old gentleman politely informs Huck that he will be searched for weapons, emphasizing it's merely a precautionary measure without ill intent, and then performs a superficial pat-down.
He encourages Huck to feel at ease and recount his story, but the old lady, Rachel, compassionately interrupts, pointing out Huck's drenched and likely hungry condition.
Rachel directs Betsy, a Black woman working for the family, to quickly prepare some food for Huck.
She then suggests one of the young women wake her son, Buck, to provide Huck with dry clothing, but Buck appears on his own initiative.
Buck, a youth roughly Huck's age, enters looking sleepy and disheveled, dragging a gun, and immediately inquires about the presence of Shepherdsons.
Learning it was a false alarm, Buck expresses a boyish regret, wishing he could have confronted a Shepherdson, which elicits laughter from the family.
Bob teases Buck about his tardiness, joking that his delay could have resulted in them all being harmed.
Buck voices his frustration, feeling he's consistently denied opportunities to demonstrate his capabilities.
The old man reassures Buck that his time for action will come and instructs him to assist Huck as his mother requested.

events.text_segment:
The candle was on the floor, and there they all was, looking at me, and me at them, for about a quarter of a minute: Three big men with guns pointed at me, which made me wince, I tell you; the oldest, gray and about sixty, the other two thirty or more—all of them fine and handsome—and the sweetest old gray-headed lady, and back of her two young women which I couldn’t see right well. The old gentleman says:
“There; I reckon it’s all right. Come in.”
As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it and bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and they all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor, and got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front windows—there warn’t none on the side. They held the candle, and took a good look at me, and all said, “Why, he ain’t a Shepherdson—no, there ain’t any Shepherdson about him.” Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn’t mind being searched for arms, because he didn’t mean no harm by it—it was only to make sure. So he didn’t pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right. He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:
“Why, bless you, Saul, the poor thing’s as wet as he can be; and don’t you reckon it may be he’s hungry?”
“True for you, Rachel—I forgot.”
So the old lady says:
“Betsy” (this was a nigger woman), “you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell him—oh, here he is himself. events.title: Bonding with Buck and Recounting a Fabricated Past
detailed_summary: Upstairs in Buck's room, Huck changes into a set of Buck's dry clothes.

Before Huck can state his name, Buck launches into an animated monologue about a bluejay and a young rabbit he recently caught, followed by posing a riddle: 'Where was Moses when the candle went out?'
Huck admits he doesn't know the answer, and Buck triumphantly reveals it: 'Why, he was in the dark!'

Buck enthusiastically suggests that Huck should stay with them permanently, emphasizing the lack of school and the potential for 'booming times,' also mentioning his dog and his personal aversion to dressing up for Sundays.
Downstairs, Huck is treated to a generous meal of cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter, and buttermilk, which he declares to be the best food he has ever encountered.
During the meal, Huck eats and talks while the family members (excluding Betsy, who had left, and the two young women) smoke cob pipes and engage him in conversation.

Huck concocts a sorrowful history for himself, claiming his family lived on a small farm in Arkansas, his sister Mary Ann eloped and was never heard from again, his brother Bill disappeared while searching for her, brothers Tom and Mort died, leaving only him and his deeply troubled father, who also eventually passed away. He concludes by saying he took what little remained, started up the river as a deck passenger, and fell overboard.
Moved by his tale, the Grangerfords offer Huck a home with them for as long as he wishes to stay.
As dawn approaches, everyone heads to bed; Huck shares a bed with Buck and, upon waking the next morning, realizes with dismay that he has forgotten the false name he provided.

When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on. While I was at it he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to tell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods day before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn’t know; I hadn’t heard about it before, no way.
“Well, guess,” he says.
“How’m I going to guess,” says I, “when I never heard tell of it before?”
“But you can guess, can’t you? It’s just as easy.”
“Which candle?” I says.
“Why, any candle,” he says.
“I don’t know where he was,” says I; “where was he?”
“Why, he was in the dark! That’s where he was!”
“Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?”
“Why, blame it, it’s a riddle, don’t you see? Say, how long are you going to stay here? You got to stay always. We can just have booming times—they don’t have no school now. Do you own a dog? I’ve got a dog—and he’ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in. Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness? You bet I don’t, but ma she makes me. Confound these ole britches! I reckon I’d better put ’em on, but I’d ruther not, it’s so warm. Are you all ready? All right. Come along, old hoss.”
Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk—that is what they had for me down there, and there ain’t nothing better that ever I’ve come across yet. Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes, except the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women. They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked. The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs. They all asked me questions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living on a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann run off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went to hunt them and he warn’t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and then there warn’t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just trimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I took what there was left, because the farm didn’t belong to us, and started up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was how I come to be here. So they said I could have a home there as long as I wanted it. Then it was most daylight and everybody went to bed, and I went to bed with Buck, and when I waked up in the morning, drat it all, I had forgot what my name was.

When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on. They didn’t fit me too well, being too large in the shoulders and too short in the legs, but they were clean and dry, and that was a sight better than the rags I’d been wearing. I reckon I must’ve looked a proper fool, standing there in clothes that hung off me like a scarecrow’s outfit, but Jim didn’t laugh. He just nodded and said, “Now you look like a regular boy, Huck.”

I didn’t feel like no regular boy, though. I felt like a runaway, a liar, and a thief—which, truth be told, I was. But Jim didn’t seem to mind none. He treated me like I was somebody worth something, even though I knew I wasn’t. That was the strange thing about Jim. He saw good in folks when there wasn’t none to see.

After I’d changed, Jim rummaged around in an old chest and pulled out a pair of shoes. They was worn down at the heels and cracked at the toes, but they was better than going barefoot. I sat on the edge of his bed and laced ’em up, feeling like I was dressing up for some grand occasion instead of just trying to keep from freezing or starving.

“You hungry, Huck?” Jim asked, watching me struggle with the laces.

I nodded, though I was half-afraid to admit it. I didn’t want to be no more trouble than I already was. But Jim just smiled and said, “I got some cornbread left from supper. It ain’t much, but it’ll fill you up some.”

He went over to a little table by the window and broke off a piece of the bread, handing it to me. I took it quick, before he could change his mind, and stuffed it in my mouth. It was cold and dry, but it tasted like heaven. I hadn’t had a proper meal in days, and even stale cornbread was a feast.

While I ate, Jim sat down across from me, his big hands resting on his knees. He didn’t say nothing for a while, just studied me like he was trying to figure out a puzzle. Finally, he said, “You in some kind of trouble, Huck?”

I stopped chewing. I hadn’t planned on telling him nothing, but there was something in his voice that made me want to. Maybe it was the kindness, or maybe it was just that I was tired of lying. So I swallowed hard and said, “Yeah, Jim. I reckon I am.”

He nodded slow, like he already knew. “You wanna tell me about it?”

I looked down at my hands, all scratched up from running through the woods. “It’s a long story,” I muttered.

Jim leaned back in his chair. “We got time,” he said.

And just like that, I knew I was gonna tell him everything. Maybe it was foolish. Maybe he’d turn me in. But right then, with the moonlight coming through the window and the sound of the river outside, it felt like the only thing to do. So I took a deep breath and started talking.

events.title: The Morning After: A Name Remembered Through a Ruse
detailed_summary: Upon waking, Huck spends approximately an hour in bed, anxiously attempting to recall the alias he had given to the Grangerford family.
When Buck awakens, Huck cleverly devises a stratagem to learn his forgotten name without exposing his lapse in memory.
He challenges Buck, making a bet that Buck is incapable of spelling Huck's (assumed) name.
Buck, confident in his abilities, readily accepts the wager and proceeds to correctly spell out 'G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n.'
Huck feigns astonishment at Buck's spelling prowess, remarking that it is a notably difficult name to spell correctly on the first try without prior study.
He makes a private mental note of the spelling, resolving to commit it to memory so he can readily produce it if questioned again.

events.title: The Grandeur and Peculiarities of the Grangerford Parlor
detailed_summary: Huck reflects on the admirable qualities of the Grangerford family and the impressive nature of their house, which he considers the most stylish country residence he has ever encountered.

He observes specific details that signify its refinement, such as a brass doorknob instead of a simpler latch, and the notable absence of a bed in the parlor, a feature sometimes found in town houses.
The parlor boasts a large fireplace with meticulously cleaned bricks, occasionally enhanced with red water-paint, and equipped with substantial brass dog-irons capable of holding a large log.

A prominent clock on the mantelpiece, featuring a painted town scene on its glass front, is particularly admired by Huck for its delightful ticking sound and its peculiar habit of striking an excessive number of times after being serviced by a peddler.

The room is further adorned with an array of ornaments: brightly painted chalk parrots positioned on either side of the clock, a crockery cat and dog that emit squeaks when pressed, and decorative wild-turkey-wing fans.

A central table displays a charming crockery basket filled with artificial fruit—apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes—which, despite their vivid colors, show chips revealing their underlying material.
This table is covered with a fine oilcloth, reportedly from Philadelphia, decorated with a painted red and blue spread-eagle and an ornate border.

Books are meticulously arranged in piles on each corner of the table, including a large, illustrated family Bible, 'Pilgrim’s Progress,' which Huck found engaging but challenging, 'Friendship’s Offering,' 'Henry Clay’s Speeches,' 'Dr. Gunn’s Family Medicine,' and a hymn book.
The parlor is also furnished with well-crafted, sturdy split-bottom chairs that are in excellent condition.

events.text_segment:
It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too. I hadn’t seen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so much style. It didn’t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a wooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same as houses in town. There warn’t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a bed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them. It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too. The Grangerfords lived in a big white house with tall columns out front, like something you’d see in a picture book. Everything about it was grand—polished floors, fancy furniture, and paintings on the walls of folks who looked like they’d never done a day’s work in their lives. The kind of place where you felt like you ought to wipe your feet before stepping inside, even if they were already clean.  

Colonel Grangerford was the head of the household, a tall, stern man with a face like carved stone. He carried himself like he was used to giving orders and having folks jump to obey. But for all his seriousness, he had a way about him that made you respect him without quite knowing why. His wife was just as fine, always dressed in silks and lace, moving through the house like a queen. She had a soft voice, but you could tell she was used to being listened to.  

Then there was Miss Sophia, their daughter, who was about my age. She was pretty as a peach, with big, kind eyes and a smile that could light up a room. She took a shine to me right off, treating me like I was somebody worth knowing, not just some ragged boy floating down the river. Her brother, Buck, was near my age too, and we got along like two peas in a pod. He was full of life, always laughing or planning some mischief.  

For a while, living with the Grangerfords felt like stepping into a dream. They had servants who waited on them hand and foot, and meals were feasts—fried chicken, cornbread, pies so sweet they’d make your teeth ache. I’d never eaten so good in all my life. At night, we’d sit by the fire, and the Colonel would tell stories about the old days, back when he fought in the war. Buck would whisper to me about the feud with the Shepherdsons, a rival family who’d been enemies with the Grangerfords for so long nobody could remember how it started.  

But as nice as it all was, there was something uneasy underneath. The way Buck talked about the Shepherdsons, his eyes darkening like storm clouds, made me nervous. The Grangerfords were good people, but they had a hardness in them when it came to that feud. It was like a sickness, eating away at them, though they didn’t see it.  

Then one day, Miss Sophia ran off with one of the Shepherdson boys. The whole house turned upside down. The Colonel’s face went white as chalk, and Buck grabbed his gun, his hands shaking with rage. I tried to tell him it wasn’t worth dying over, but he wouldn’t listen. Nobody would.  

The next morning, the fighting started. Gunshots echoed through the woods, and by the time it was over, Buck and his cousin were dead. I found them lying in the shallows of the river, their blood staining the water. It was the saddest, most useless thing I’d ever seen.  

I slipped away that night, back to the raft with Jim. The Grangerfords’ house, with all its grandeur, felt like a tomb now. I reckoned there wasn’t no family so fine that hate couldn’t ruin them. And I knew then that I’d had enough of feuds and foolishness. The river was calling, and it was time to move on.

events.title: Emmeline Grangerford: A Legacy of Melancholy Art and Poetry
detailed_summary: Huck describes the various pictures hanging on the walls, which include depictions of Washingtons, Lafayettes, battle scenes, Highland Marys, and one titled 'Signing the Declaration.'

He gives special attention to a collection of crayon drawings created by the family's deceased daughter, Emmeline, when she was merely fifteen years old, noting their predominantly dark and somber quality, which he found unusual.

He provides detailed descriptions of several of Emmeline's melancholic artworks: one featuring a woman in a slim black dress mourning by a tombstone under a weeping willow, captioned 'Shall I Never See Thee More Alas'; another portraying a young lady weeping into a handkerchief while holding a dead bird, titled 'I Shall Never Hear Thy Sweet Chirrup More Alas'; and a third showing a tearful young lady at a window gazing at the moon, clutching an open letter, with the caption 'And Art Thou Gone Yes Thou Art Gone Alas.'
Huck confesses that while these pictures were considered fine, they invariably made him feel uneasy or 'gave him the fan-tods.'

He recounts the story of Emmeline's ambitious but unfinished painting: a young woman in a long white gown poised to jump from a bridge, depicted with multiple sets of arms because Emmeline passed away before deciding on the final pose. This picture is preserved above the head of the bed in her room and adorned with flowers on her birthday.
Huck observes that the subject of this painting had a sweet face but appeared 'too spidery' due to the profusion of arms.

Emmeline also maintained a scrapbook where she pasted obituaries, accounts of accidents, and stories of suffering from the 'Presbyterian Observer,' which then inspired her to write poetry, exemplified by her 'ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DEC’D,' a poem about a boy who drowned in a well.
Huck expresses admiration for her youthful talent, and Buck's accounts confirm Emmeline's prolific and rapid poetic output, always focusing on sad themes.

She gained a local reputation for her promptly composed 'tributes' for deceased individuals, reportedly faltering only once when she struggled to find a rhyme for the name 'Whistler,' an incident after which her spirits and health seemingly declined.

Despite sometimes being unsettled by her morbid creations, Huck felt an affinity for the entire Grangerford family, including the departed Emmeline, and would often retreat to her room to read her scrapbook.
Feeling that Emmeline herself deserved a poetic tribute after her death, Huck attempted to write some verses for her but found himself unable to succeed.
Emmeline's room is kept meticulously preserved by the old lady, just as it was when she was alive, and serves as a private space for sewing and Bible reading.

They had pictures hung on the walls—mainly Washingtons and Lafayettes, and battles, and Highland Marys, and one called “Signing the Declaration.” There was some that they called crayons, which one of the daughters which was dead made her own self when she was only fifteen years old. They was different from any pictures I ever see before—blacker, mostly, than is common. One was a woman in a slim black dress, belted small under the armpits, with bulges like a cabbage in the middle of the sleeves, and a large black scoop-shovel bonnet with a black veil, and white slim ankles crossed about with black tape, and very wee black slippers, like a chisel, and she was leaning pensive on a tombstone on her right elbow, under a weeping willow, and her other hand hanging down her side holding a white handkerchief and a reticule, and underneath the picture it said “Shall I Never See Thee More Alas.” Another one was a young lady with her hair all combed up straight to the top of her head, and knotted there in front of a comb like a chair-back, and she was crying into a handkerchief and had a dead bird laying on its back in her other hand with its heels up, and underneath the picture it said “I Shall Never Hear Thy Sweet Chirrup More Alas.” There was one where a young lady was at a window looking up at the moon, and tears running down her cheeks; and she had an open letter in one hand with black sealing wax showing on one edge of it, and she was mashing a locket with a chain to it against her mouth, and underneath the picture it said “And Art Thou Gone Yes Thou Art Gone Alas.” These was all nice pictures, I reckon, but I didn’t somehow seem to take to them, because if ever I was down a little they always give me the fan-tods. Everybody was sorry she died, because she had laid out a lot more of these pictures to do, and a body could see by what she had done what they had lost. But I reckoned that with her disposition she was having a better time in the graveyard. She was at work on what they said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it done, but she never got the chance. It was a picture of a young woman in a long white gown, standing on the rail of a bridge all ready to jump off, with her hair all down her back, and looking up to the moon, with the tears running down her face, and she had two arms folded across her breast, and two arms stretched out in front, and two more reaching up towards the moon—and the idea was to see which pair would look best, and then scratch out all the other arms; but, as I was saying, she died before she got her mind made up, and now they kept this picture over the head of the bed in her room, and every time her birthday come they hung flowers on it. Other times it was hid with a little curtain. The young woman in the picture had a kind of a nice sweet face, but there was so many arms it made her look too spidery, seemed to me.
This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the Presbyterian Observer, and write poetry after them out of her own head. It was very good poetry. This is what she wrote about a boy by the name of Stephen Dowling Bots that fell down a well and was drownded:
ODE TO STEPHEN DOWLING BOTS, DEC’D

And did young Stephen sicken,
    And did young Stephen die?
And did the sad hearts thicken,
    And did the mourners cry?

No; such was not the fate of
    Young Stephen Dowling Bots;
Though sad hearts round him thickened,
    ’Twas not from sickness’ shots.

No whooping-cough did rack his frame,
    Nor measles drear with spots;
Not these impaired the sacred name
    Of Stephen Dowling Bots.

Despised love struck not with woe
    That head of curly knots,
Nor stomach troubles laid him low,
    Young Stephen Dowling Bots.

O no. Then list with tearful eye,
    Whilst I his fate do tell.
His soul did from this cold world fly
    By falling down a well.

They got him out and emptied him;
    Alas it was too late;
His spirit was gone for to sport aloft
    In the realms of the good and great.
If Emmeline Grangerford could make poetry like that before she was fourteen, there ain’t no telling what she could a done by-and-by. Buck said she could rattle off poetry like nothing. She didn’t ever have to stop to think. He said she would slap down a line, and if she couldn’t find anything to rhyme with it would just scratch it out and slap down another one, and go ahead. She warn’t particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful. Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her “tribute” before he was cold. She called them tributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertaker—the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person’s name, which was Whistler. She warn’t ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long. Poor thing, many’s the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little. I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn’t going to let anything come between us. Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn’t seem right that there warn’t nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn’t seem to make it go somehow. They kept Emmeline’s room trim and nice, and all the things fixed in it just the way she liked to have them when she was alive, and nobody ever slept there. The old lady took care of the room herself, though there was plenty of niggers, and she sewed there a good deal and read her Bible there mostly.

She warn’t particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful. Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her “tribute” before he was cold. She called them tributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertaker—the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person’s name, which was Whistler. She warn’t ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long. Poor thing, many’s the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little. I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn’t going to let anything come between us. Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn’t seem right that there warn’t nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn’t seem to make it go somehow. They kept Emmeline’s room trim and nice, and all the things fixed in it just the way she liked to have them when she was alive, and nobody ever slept there. The old lady took care of the room herself, though there was plenty of niggers, and she sewed there a good deal and read her Bible there mostly.

The walls of the house were covered with an odd assortment of pictures, each one telling a story of its own. There was General Washington, stiff and solemn in his blue coat, looking as though he’d never cracked a smile in his life. Next to him hung the Marquis de Lafayette, all frills and lace, with a sword at his side and a look that said he’d just stepped out of a fancy ball.  

Then there were the battle scenes—great, sprawling things with smoke and soldiers and horses rearing up in terror. One showed a line of redcoats firing into a crowd of ragged patriots, while another had a cavalry charge with sabers flashing in the sun. I reckon whoever painted those must’ve had a powerful imagination, ‘cause the way the men were posed, you’d think war was nothing but glory and heroics, with no mud or blood or dying groans to spoil the picture.  

But the queerest of all was the one called *Highland Mary*. She was a pale, sorrowful-looking woman in a long white dress, standing by a river with her hands clasped like she was praying or saying goodbye. There was something mournful about her, like she knew some terrible secret but couldn’t bring herself to speak it. I asked Aunt Sally once who she was, and she said it was some old Scottish song about lost love, but I never could figure why anybody’d want to hang such a gloomy thing on their wall.  

Then, right in the middle of the room, was the biggest picture of all: *Signing the Declaration*. It showed a bunch of men in wigs and knee-breeches gathered around a table, looking mighty serious as they put their names to that famous paper. One fellow had his hand raised like he was making a speech, and another was leaning over to whisper in his neighbor’s ear. Off to the side stood a tall, thin man with a long nose—Mr. Jefferson, I reckon—holding a quill like he was about to write something grand.  

I studied that picture a good long while, trying to make sense of it. Here were all these fine gentlemen, dressed up like they were going to a king’s court, signing away their loyalty to England and declaring themselves free. It was a powerful notion, but it struck me as funny, too—how a piece of paper could start a war, and how men who looked like they’d never done a hard day’s work in their lives could decide the fate of a whole country.  

Aunt Sally was mighty proud of that picture. She said it was a lesson in patriotism and that every American ought to have one in their home. But I couldn’t help wondering what Jim would’ve thought of it—him being a slave and all, and the Declaration talking so high and mighty about liberty. Seemed to me there was a heap of difference between what those men wrote and what they actually did.

Me, I preferred the ones with the battles. At least those showed a little action.

He also notes the presence of a 'little old piano,' which he suspects had tin pans inside contributing to its sound, and expresses that hearing the young ladies sing 'The Last Link is Broken' and play 'The Battle of Prague' on it was an exceptionally lovely experience.

The interior walls throughout the house were plastered, most of the rooms featured carpets on the floors, and the entire exterior of the house was whitewashed, all indicative of a well-maintained and comfortable dwelling.

Huck describes the house's unique 'double house' structure, which included a large, open area between the two main sections that was both roofed and floored. This space was sometimes used for setting the table for meals during the day, offering a cool and pleasant dining environment.
He concludes his observations with enthusiastic praise for the exceptional quality and generous abundance of the food served at the Grangerford home, emphasizing that nothing could be better.

There was a little old piano, too, that had tin pans in it, I reckon, and nothing was ever so lovely as to hear the young ladies sing “The Last Link is Broken” and play “The Battle of Prague” on it. The walls of all the rooms was plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.
It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the day, and it was a cool, comfortable place. Nothing couldn’t be better. And warn’t the cooking good, and just bushels of it too!

events.title: Colonel Grangerford's Aristocratic Demeanor and Family Rituals
detailed_summary: The narrator, Huck Finn, provides a detailed description of Colonel Grangerford, portraying him as the epitome of a Southern gentleman, emphasizing his distinguished lineage, physical appearance—tall, slim, with a pale complexion and intense dark eyes—and his impeccable habit of wearing clean white linen suits daily and a blue tail-coat on Sundays.
Colonel Grangerford's character is depicted as inherently kind, inspiring confidence, yet capable of a formidable sternness that commanded respect without explicit demands for good manners.
A daily morning ritual is described: the entire family rises when the Colonel and his wife appear. His sons, Tom and Bob, then mix and serve him a glass of bitters. After a formal exchange of
they all drink, with Huck and Buck also receiving a diluted version of the drink to toast their elders.
Tom and Bob Grangerford are introduced as tall, handsome men with broad shoulders, dark features, and, like their father, dressed in white linen and Panama hats.
Miss Charlotte, twenty-five, is characterized as tall, proud, grand, and beautiful, generally good-natured unless provoked, at which point she could display a daunting look similar to her father's.
Her sister, Miss Sophia, twenty years old, is described as beautiful in a different manner—gentle, sweet, and dove-like.
It is noted that each family member, including Buck, had a personal slave to attend to them. Huck remarks that his own slave had an easy time, as Huck was unaccustomed to being waited on.
The narrative reveals that the family was once larger, but three sons had been killed, and a daughter named Emmeline had also passed away.

Colonel Grangerford's significant wealth is highlighted by his ownership of many farms and over a hundred slaves. Their home frequently hosted large gatherings of kinfolk from miles around, involving days of festivities, hunting, river excursions, dances, and balls.

events.text_segment:
Col. Grangerford was a gentleman, you see. He was a gentleman all over; and so was his family. He was well born, as the saying is, and that’s worth as much in a man as it is in a horse, so the Widow Douglas said, and nobody ever denied that she was of the first aristocracy in our town; and pap he always said it, too, though he warn’t no more quality than a mudcat himself. Col. Grangerford was very tall and very slim, and had a darkish-paly complexion, not a sign of red in it anywheres; he was clean shaved every morning all over his thin face, and he had the thinnest kind of lips, and the thinnest kind of nostrils, and a high nose, and heavy eyebrows, and the blackest kind of eyes, sunk so deep back that they seemed like they was looking out of caverns at you, as you may say. His forehead was high, and his hair was black and straight and hung to his shoulders. His hands was long and thin, and every day of his life he put on a clean shirt and a full suit from head to foot made out of linen so white it hurt your eyes to look at it; and on Sundays he wore a blue tail-coat with brass buttons on it. He carried a mahogany cane with a silver head to it. There warn’t no frivolishness about him, not a bit, and he warn’t ever loud. He was as kind as he could be—you could feel that, you know, and so you had confidence. Sometimes he smiled, and it was good to see; but when he straightened himself up like a liberty-pole, and the lightning begun to flicker out from under his eyebrows, you wanted to climb a tree first, and find out what the matter was afterwards. He didn’t ever have to tell anybody to mind their manners—everybody was always good-mannered where he was. Everybody loved to have him around, too; he was sunshine most always—I mean he made it seem like good weather. When he turned into a cloudbank it was awful dark for half a minute, and that was enough; there wouldn’t nothing go wrong again for a week.
When him and the old lady come down in the morning all the family got up out of their chairs and give them good-day, and didn’t set down again till they had set down. Then Tom and Bob went to the sideboard where the decanter was, and mixed a glass of bitters and handed it to him, and he held it in his hand and waited till Tom’s and Bob’s was mixed, and then they bowed and said, “Our duty to you, sir, and madam;” and they bowed the least bit in the world and said thank you, and so they drank, all three, and Bob and Tom poured a spoonful of water on the sugar and the mite of whisky or apple brandy in the bottom of their tumblers, and give it to me and Buck, and we drank to the old people too.
Bob was the oldest and Tom next—tall, beautiful men with very broad shoulders and brown faces, and long black hair and black eyes. They dressed in white linen from head to foot, like the old gentleman, and wore broad Panama hats.
Then there was Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five, and tall and proud and grand, but as good as she could be when she warn’t stirred up; but when she was, she had a look that would make you wilt in your tracks, like her father. She was beautiful.
So was her sister, Miss Sophia, but it was a different kind. She was gentle and sweet like a dove, and she was only twenty.
Each person had their own nigger to wait on them—Buck too. My nigger had a monstrous easy time, because I warn’t used to having anybody do anything for me, but Buck’s was on the jump most of the time.
This was all there was of the family now, but there used to be more—three sons; they got killed; and Emmeline that died.
The old gentleman owned a lot of farms and over a hundred niggers. Sometimes a stack of people would come there, horseback, from ten or fifteen mile around, and stay five or six days, and have such junketings round about and on the river, and dances and picnics in the woods daytimes, and balls at the house nights. These people was mostly kinfolks of the family. The men brought their guns with them. It was a handsome lot of quality, I tell you.
