events.text_segment:
But the old man got pretty silent by-and-by—didn’t have much to say, and didn’t look pretty comfortable over all that petting that was going on around that duke. He seemed to have something on his mind. So, along in the afternoon, he says:
“Looky here, Bilgewater,” he says, “I’m nation sorry for you, but you ain’t the only person that’s had troubles like that.”
“No?”
“No you ain’t. You ain’t the only person that’s ben snaked down wrongfully out’n a high place.”
“Alas!”
“No, you ain’t the only person that’s had a secret of his birth.” And, by jings, he begins to cry.
“Hold! What do you mean?”
“Bilgewater, kin I trust you?” says the old man, still sort of sobbing.
“To the bitter death!” He took the old man by the hand and squeezed it, and says, “That secret of your being: speak!”
“Bilgewater, I am the late Dauphin!”
You bet you, Jim and me stared this time. Then the duke says:
“You are what?”
“Yes, my friend, it is too true—your eyes is lookin’ at this very moment on the pore disappeared Dauphin, Looy the Seventeen, son of Looy the Sixteen and Marry Antonette.”
“You! At your age! No! You mean you’re the late Charlemagne; you must be six or seven hundred years old, at the very least.”
“Trouble has done it, Bilgewater, trouble has done it; trouble has brung these gray hairs and this premature balditude. Yes, gentlemen, you see before you, in blue jeans and misery, the wanderin’, exiled, trampled-on, and sufferin’ rightful King of France.”
Well, he cried and took on so that me and Jim didn’t know hardly what to do, we was so sorry—and so glad and proud we’d got him with us, too. So we set in, like we done before with the duke, and tried to comfort him. But he said it warn’t no use, nothing but to be dead and done with it all could do him any good; though he said it often made him feel easier and better for a while if people treated him according to his rights, and got down on one knee to speak to him, and always called him “Your Majesty,” and waited on him first at meals, and didn’t set down in his presence till he asked them. So Jim and me set to majestying him, and doing this and that and t’other for him, and standing up till he told us we might set down. This done him heaps of good, and so he got cheerful and comfortable. events.title: Huck's Astute Realization and Pragmatic Decision for Peace
detailed_summary: Huck quickly discerned that the two newcomers were not genuine royalty but were, in fact, common swindlers and deceivers.
Despite this realization, he decided not to reveal his knowledge or challenge their claims.
He concluded that maintaining silence and feigning belief was the most effective strategy to prevent arguments and avoid trouble.
He was willing to address them as kings and dukes if it helped maintain peace within their group, which he thought of as 'the family.'
Furthermore, he saw no benefit in informing Jim of his suspicions, so he kept this insight to himself.

Huck reflected on a lesson learned from his father, Pap: the most practical way to deal with people like the two con men was to allow them to have their own way, thus ensuring a smoother and less confrontational coexistence.

They asked us considerable many questions; wanted to know what we covered up the raft that way for, and laid by in the daytime instead of running—was Jim a runaway nigger?  

Well, I could see they was suspicious, and I reckoned I’d have to think up something quick. So I put on my most innocent face and said, “Goodness, no! That ain’t no runaway. He’s my nigger—been with our family since I was knee-high to a grasshopper. We’re just travelin’ down to Orleans to see my uncle, and we cover the raft ‘cause the sun’s mighty fierce this time of year. Jim’s got a touch of the rheumatism, so we take it slow by day and float at night when it’s cooler.”  

The men looked at each other, then back at me, squinting like they was tryin’ to see right through me. One of ‘em, a lean fellow with a sharp nose, said, “That so? Well, why ain’t you on a steamboat, then? Ain’t no boy travelin’ all that way on a raft with just a nigger for company.”  

I swallowed hard but kept my voice steady. “Steamboats cost money, mister. My uncle sent word we was to come, but he didn’t send no fare. So we fixed up this raft and set out. Jim’s real good at takin’ care of me—cooks my meals and keeps me out of trouble.”  

The other man, a burly sort with a thick beard, scratched his chin. “You got any papers to prove he’s yours?”  

My heart near about stopped. Papers? I hadn’t reckoned on that. But then I remembered somethin’ Pap used to say. “Papers?” I scoffed. “Ain’t nobody round our parts bother with papers. Everybody knows Jim belongs to us. Why, you can ask anybody up in St. Petersburg—they’ll tell you.”  

They studied me a minute longer, then the sharp-nosed one shrugged. “Well, all right. But you best keep movin’. There’s been talk of runaways along this stretch.”  

I nodded real eager-like. “Yes, sir, we sure will. Thank you kindly.”  

Soon as they rowed off, I let out a breath I didn’t know I was holdin’. Jim peeked out from under the wigwam, his face pale. “Dat was too close, Huck,” he whispered.  

“Sure was,” I said. “But we got through it. Now let’s shove off ‘fore anybody else takes a notion to ask questions.”

Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat lightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was beginning to shiver—it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see that. So the duke and the king went to overhauling our wigwam, to see what the beds was like. My bed was a straw tick better than Jim’s, which was a corn-shuck tick; there’s always cobs around about in a shuck tick, and they poke into you and hurt; and when you roll over the dry shucks sound like you was rolling over in a pile of dead leaves; it makes such a rustling that you wake up. Well, the duke allowed he would take my bed; but the king allowed he wouldn’t. He says:
“I should a reckoned the difference in rank would a sejested to you that a corn-shuck bed warn’t just fitten for me to sleep on. Your Grace’ll take the shuck bed yourself.”
Jim and me was in a sweat again for a minute, being afraid there was going to be some more trouble amongst them; so we was pretty glad when the duke says:
“’Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of oppression. Misfortune has broken my once haughty spirit; I yield, I submit; ’tis my fate. I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”

We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The king told us to stand well out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we got a long ways below the town. We come in sight of the little bunch of lights by-and-by—that was the town, you know—and slid by, about a half a mile out, all right. When we was three-quarters of a mile below we hoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o’clock it come on to rain and blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us to both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the duke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night. It was my watch below till twelve, but I wouldn’t a turned in anyway if I’d had a bed, because a body don’t see such a storm as that every day in the week, not by a long sight. My souls, how the wind did scream along! And every second or two there’d come a glare that lit up the white-caps for a half a mile around, and you’d see the islands looking dusty through the rain, and the trees thrashing around in the wind; then comes a h-whack!—bum! bum! bumble-umble-um-bum-bum-bum-bum—and the thunder would go rumbling and grumbling away, and quit—and then rip comes another flash and another sockdolager. The waves most washed me off the raft sometimes, but I hadn’t any clothes on, and didn’t mind. We didn’t have no trouble about snags; the lightning was glaring and flittering around so constant that we could see them plenty soon enough to throw her head this way or that and miss them.
I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warn’t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.

We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The moon hadn’t risen yet, and the river was black as ink, with only the faintest ripple where the current ran swift. Jim and I pushed the raft out quiet as shadows, careful not to make a sound that might carry over the water. The night air was thick with the hum of crickets and the occasional hoot of an owl, but otherwise, the world seemed to hold its breath.  

I reckon there ain’t nothing quite like the feeling of slipping away under cover of darkness—knowing you’re leaving trouble behind, even if you ain’t quite sure what lies ahead. Jim stood at the back of the raft, poling us along, his big shoulders working steady and silent. I sat up front, keeping my eyes peeled for snags or sandbars, though in that blackness, it was more guesswork than sight.  

The further we got from shore, the lighter I felt, like a weight had been lifted off my chest. Jim must’ve felt it too, ‘cause after a while, he let out a long breath and said real low, “We’s doin’ it, Huck. We’s really doin’ it.”  

I nodded, even though he couldn’t see me. “Ain’t nobody gonna find us now,” I whispered back.  

The stars came out slow, one by one, till the whole sky was lit up like somebody had scattered diamonds on black velvet. The river stretched out ahead of us, wide and mysterious, carrying us toward whatever was next. I reckon some folks might’ve been scared, floating into the unknown like that, but I wasn’t. Not with Jim there. He was the steadiest friend a feller could ask for, and as long as we stuck together, I figured we’d be all right.  

After a while, the current took hold proper, and Jim laid down his pole. We let the raft drift, trusting the river to guide us. The water lapped soft against the logs, and the night wrapped around us like a blanket. Jim hummed a little tune under his breath—some old song from his childhood—and I leaned back, staring up at the stars, thinking how strange it was that just a few hours ago, we’d been trapped, and now here we were, free as birds.  

I reckon freedom ain’t always about knowing where you’re headed. Sometimes it’s just about knowing what you’re leaving behind. And as the raft carried us further into the dark, I felt something I hadn’t in a long time—hope.  

Jim must’ve felt it too, ‘cause after a while, he said, “We gonna make it, Huck. One way or another.”

We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most awful hot day. The sun beat down on us something fierce, and the air was so thick with humidity it felt like we were breathing through a wet blanket. Even the trees along the riverbank seemed to sag under the weight of the heat, their leaves hanging limp and lifeless.  

Jim wiped his forehead with the back of his hand and sighed. "Dis heat ain't natural, Huck," he said. "Feels like de whole world's fixin' to catch fire."  

I nodded, too miserable to speak. My shirt clung to my back like a second skin, and my boots squelched with every step from the sweat running down my legs. The only relief came when a faint breeze stirred the air, but even that was warm and did little more than remind us how still and heavy the day was.  

We’d been making our way downriver, keeping to the shallows where the current wasn’t so strong, but the heat made even that slow progress feel like hard labor. The water, usually cool and inviting, was warm as bathwater, and the fish weren’t biting—likely hiding in the deeper, cooler parts of the river.  

Jim shaded his eyes with his hand and squinted up at the sky. "Ain’t no clouds nowheres," he muttered. "Ain’t gon’ rain to break dis heat, neither."  

I didn’t doubt him. The sky was a pale, washed-out blue, bleached by the sun, without so much as a wisp of cloud to offer shade. Even the birds had gone quiet, hiding in whatever shade they could find. The only sound was the occasional buzz of a cicada, its shrill song cutting through the thick air like a saw.  

We trudged on, our feet dragging in the dust. The island we were heading for wasn’t much farther, but in that heat, every step felt like a mile. I thought longingly of the cool spring we’d found a few days back, where the water bubbled up clear and cold from the ground. But that was behind us now, and all we could do was keep moving forward.  

Finally, just when I thought I might drop from exhaustion, we reached the spot where the trees grew thicker, their branches weaving together to form a patch of shade. Jim and I both sank down onto the ground, too tired to even speak for a minute. The earth beneath us was warm, but the shade made it bearable.  

Jim pulled out his canteen and took a long drink before passing it to me. The water inside was warm, but it still tasted like heaven. I drank deep, then wiped my mouth with my sleeve.  

"We best rest here a spell," Jim said, leaning back against a tree trunk. "Ain’t no use killin’ ourselves in dis heat."  

I nodded, too grateful for the break to argue. The shade didn’t make the day any cooler, but it gave us a chance to catch our breath. And for now, that was enough.

events.title: The King's 'Reformed Pirate' Con at the Camp Meeting
detailed_summary: Suddenly, the king began making loud noises and charged onto the preacher's platform; the preacher invited him to address the crowd.
The king then spun a tale, claiming to be a pirate for thirty years in the Indian Ocean whose crew had been decimated in a recent fight.
He said he had returned to recruit fresh men but was blessedly robbed and left penniless, an event he claimed led to his happy conversion.
He declared his intention to return to the Indian Ocean, despite his poverty, to dedicate his life to reforming pirates, asserting his unique ability to do so due to his familiarity with them.
He emotionally told the crowd that any pirate he converted would be instructed to credit the people of Pokeville camp meeting and the preacher.
The king's story brought himself and the entire audience to tears.
Someone suggested taking up a collection, and another proposed the king himself pass the hat, an idea endorsed by everyone, including the preacher.
The king moved through the crowd, collecting money while feigning tears, blessing the people, and being kissed by emotional young women.
He declined invitations to stay, citing his urgent mission to the Indian Ocean.
Back at the raft, the king counted his collection: eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents, plus a three-gallon jug of whisky he found.
He boasted that this day's earnings surpassed any from his supposed missionary work, claiming pirates were far more effective than heathens for swindling camp meetings.

Well, the first I knowed the king got a-going, and you could hear him over everybody; and next he went a-charging up on to the platform, and the preacher he begged him to speak to the people, and he done it. He told them he was a pirate—been a pirate for thirty years out in the Indian Ocean—and his crew was thinned out considerable last spring in a fight, and he was home now to take out some fresh men, and thanks to goodness he’d been robbed last night and put ashore off of a steamboat without a cent, and he was glad of it; it was the blessedest thing that ever happened to him, because he was a changed man now, and happy for the first time in his life; and, poor as he was, he was going to start right off and work his way back to the Indian Ocean, and put in the rest of his life trying to turn the pirates into the true path; for he could do it better than anybody else, being acquainted with all pirate crews in that ocean; and though it would take him a long time to get there without money, he would get there anyway, and every time he convinced a pirate he would say to him, “Don’t you thank me, don’t you give me no credit; it all belongs to them dear people in Pokeville camp-meeting, natural brothers and benefactors of the race, and that dear preacher there, the truest friend a pirate ever had!”
And then he busted into tears, and so did everybody. Then somebody sings out, “Take up a collection for him, take up a collection!” Well, a half a dozen made a jump to do it, but somebody sings out, “Let him pass the hat around!” Then everybody said it, the preacher too.
So the king went all through the crowd with his hat swabbing his eyes, and blessing the people and praising them and thanking them for being so good to the poor pirates away off there; and every little while the prettiest kind of girls, with the tears running down their cheeks, would up and ask him would he let them kiss him for to remember him by; and he always done it; and some of them he hugged and kissed as many as five or six times—and he was invited to stay a week; and everybody wanted him to live in their houses, and said they’d think it was an honor; but he said as this was the last day of the camp-meeting he couldn’t do no good, and besides he was in a sweat to get to the Indian Ocean right off and go to work on the pirates.
When we got back to the raft and he come to count up he found he had collected eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents. And then he had fetched away a three-gallon jug of whisky, too, that he found under a wagon when he was starting home through the woods. The king said, take it all around, it laid over any day he’d ever put in in the missionarying line. He said it warn’t no use talking, heathens don’t amount to shucks alongside of pirates to work a camp-meeting with.

The duke was thinking he’d been doing pretty well till the king come to show up, but after that he didn’t think so so much. He had set up and printed off two little jobs for farmers in that printing-office—horse bills—and took the money, four dollars. And he had got in ten dollars’ worth of advertisements for the paper, which he said he would put in for four dollars if they would pay in advance—so they done it. The price of the paper was two dollars a year, but he took in three subscriptions for half a dollar apiece on condition of them paying him in advance; they were going to pay in cordwood and onions as usual, but he said he had just bought the concern and knocked down the price as low as he could afford it, and was going to run it for cash. He set up a little piece of poetry, which he made, himself, out of his own head—three verses—kind of sweet and saddish—the name of it was, “Yes, crush, cold world, this breaking heart”—and he left that all set up and ready to print in the paper, and didn’t charge nothing for it. Well, he took in nine dollars and a half, and said he’d done a pretty square day’s work for it.
Then he showed us another little job he’d printed and hadn’t charged for, because it was for us. It had a picture of a runaway nigger with a bundle on a stick over his shoulder, and “$200 reward” under it. The reading was all about Jim, and just described him to a dot. It said he run away from St. Jacques’ plantation, forty mile below New Orleans, last winter, and likely went north, and whoever would catch him and send him back he could have the reward and expenses.
“Now,” says the duke, “after to-night we can run in the daytime if we want to. Whenever we see anybody coming we can tie Jim hand and foot with a rope, and lay him in the wigwam and show this handbill and say we captured him up the river, and were too poor to travel on a steamboat, so we got this little raft on credit from our friends and are going down to get the reward. Handcuffs and chains would look still better on Jim, but it wouldn’t go well with the story of us being so poor. Too much like jewelry. Ropes are the correct thing—we must preserve the unities, as we say on the boards.”

That was all right as far as it went, but the towhead warn’t sixty yards long, and the minute I flew by the foot of it I shot out into the solid white fog, and hadn’t no more idea which way I was going than a dead man.  

Thinks I, it won’t do to paddle; first I know I’ll run into the bank or a towhead or something; I got to set still and float, and yet it’s mighty fidgety business to have to hold your hands still at such a time. I whooped and listened. Away down there somewheres I hears a small whoop, and up comes my spirits. I went tearing after it, listening sharp to hear it again. The next time it come I see I warn’t heading for it, but heading away to the right of it. And the next time I was heading away to the left of it—and not gaining on it much either, for I was flying around, this way and that and t’other, but it was going straight ahead all the time.  

I did wish the fool would think to beat a tin pan, and beat it all the time, but he never did, and it was the still places between the whoops that was making the trouble for me. Well, I fought along, and directly I hears the whoop behind me. I was tangled good now. That was somebody else’s whoop, or else I was turned around.  

I throwed the paddle down. I heard the whoop again; it was behind me yet, but in a different place; it kept coming, and kept changing its place, and I kept answering, till by and by it was in front of me again, and I knowed the current had swung the canoe’s head down-stream, and I was all right if that was Jim and not some other raftsman hollering. I couldn’t tell nothing about voices in a fog, for nothing don’t look natural nor sound natural in a fog.  

The whooping went on, and in about a minute I come a-booming down on a cut bank with smoky ghosts of big trees on it, and the current throwed me off to the left and shot by, amongst a lot of snags that fairly roared, the current was tearing by them so swift.  

In another second or two it was solid white and still again. I set perfectly still then, listening to my heart thump, and I reckon I didn’t draw a breath while it thumped a hundred.  

I just give up then. I knowed what the matter was. That cut bank was an island, and Jim had gone down t’other side of it. It warn’t no towhead that you could float by in ten minutes. It had the big timber of a regular island; it might be five or six miles long and more than half a mile wide.  

I kept quiet, with my ears cocked, about fifteen minutes, I reckon. I was floating along, of course, four or five miles an hour; but you don’t ever think of that. No, you feel like you are laying dead still on the water; and if a little glimpse of a snag slips by you don’t think to yourself how fast you’re going, but you catch your breath and think, my! how that snag’s tearing along. If you think it ain’t dismal and lonesome out in a fog that way by yourself in the night, you try it once—you’ll see.  

Next, for about a half an hour, I whoops now and then; at last I hears the answer a long ways off, and tries to follow it, but I couldn’t do it, and directly I judged I’d got into a nest of towheads, for I had little dim glimpses of them on both sides of me—sometimes just a narrow channel between, and some that I couldn’t see I knowed was there because I’d hear the wash of the current against the old dead brush and trash that hung over the banks. Well, I warn’t long losing the whoops down amongst the towheads; and I only tried to chase them a little while, anyway, because it was worse than chasing a Jack-o’-lantern. You never knowed a sound dodge around so, and swap places so quick and so much.  

I had to claw away from the bank pretty lively four or five times, to keep from knocking the islands out of the river; and so I judged the raft must be butting into the bank every now and then, or else it would get further ahead and clear out of hearing—it was floating a little faster than what I was.  

Well, I seemed to be in the open river again by and by, but I couldn’t hear no sign of a whoop nowheres. I reckoned Jim had fetched up on a snag, maybe, and it was all up with him. I was good and tired, so I laid down in the canoe and said I wouldn’t bother no more. I didn’t want to go to sleep, of course; but I was so sleepy I couldn’t help it; so I thought I would take jest one little cat-nap.  

But I reckon it was more than a cat-nap, for when I waked up the stars was shining bright, the fog was all gone, and I was spinning down a big bend stern first. First I didn’t know where I was; I thought I was dreaming; and when things begun to come back to me they seemed to come up dim out of last week.  

It was a monstrous big river here, with the tallest and the thickest kind of timber on both banks; just a solid wall, as well as I could see by the stars. I looked away down-stream, and seen a black speck on the water. I took after it; but when I got to it it warn’t nothing but a couple of sawlogs made fast together. Then I see another speck, and chased that; then another, and this time I was right. It was the raft.  

When I got to it Jim was setting there with his head down between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering-oar. The other oar was smashed off, and the raft was littered up with leaves and branches and dirt. So she’d had a rough time.  

I made fast and laid down under Jim’s nose on the raft, and begun to gap, and stretch my fists out against Jim, and says:  

“Hello, Jim, have I been asleep? Why didn’t you stir me up?”  

“Goodness gracious, is dat you, Huck? En you ain’ dead—you ain’ drownded—you’s back agin? It’s too good for true, honey, it’s too good for true. Lemme look at you chile, lemme feel o’ you. No, you ain’ dead! you’s back agin, ’live en soun’, jis de same ole Huck—de same ole Huck, thanks to goodness!”  

“What’s the matter with you, Jim? You been a-drinking?”  

“Drinkin’? Has I ben a-drinkin’? Has I had a chance to be a-drinkin’?”  

“Well, then, what makes you talk so wild?”  

“How does I talk wild?”  

“How? Why, hain’t you been talking about my coming back, and all that stuff, as if I’d been gone away?”  

“Huck—Huck Finn, you look me in de eye; look me in de eye. Hain’t you ben gone away?”  

“Gone away? Why, what in the nation do you mean? I hain’t been gone anywheres. Where would I go to?”  

“Well, looky here, boss, dey’s sumf’n wrong, dey is. Is I me, or who is I? Is I heah, or whah is I? Now dat’s what I wants to know.”  

“Well, I think you’re here, plain enough, but I think you’re a tangle-headed old fool, Jim.”  

“I is, is I? Well, you answer me dis: Didn’t you tote out de line in de canoe fer to make fas’ to de towhead?”  

“No, I didn’t. What towhead? I hain’t seen no towhead.”  

“You hain’t seen no towhead? Looky here, didn’t de line pull loose en de raf’ go a-hummin’ down de river, en leave you en de canoe behine in de fog?”  

“What fog?”  

“Why, de fog!—de fog dat’s been aroun’ all night. En didn’t you whoop, en didn’t I whoop, tell we got mix’ up in de islands en one un us got los’ en t’other one was jis’ as good as los’, ’kase he didn’ know whah he wuz? En didn’t I bust up agin a lot er dem islands en have a turrible time en mos’ git drownded? Now ain’ dat so, boss—ain’t it so? You answer me dat.”  

“Well, this is too many for me, Jim. I hain’t seen no fog, nor no islands, nor no troubles, nor nothing. I been setting here talking with you all night till you went to sleep about ten minutes ago, and I reckon I done the same. You couldn’t a got drunk in that time, so of course you’ve been dreaming.”  

“Dad fetch it, how is I gwyne to dream all dat in ten minutes?”  

“Well, hang it all, you did dream it, because there didn’t any of it happen.”  

“But, Huck, it’s all jis’ as plain to me as—”  

“It don’t make no difference how plain it is; there ain’t nothing in it. I know, because I’ve been here all the time.”  

Jim didn’t say nothing for about five minutes, but set there studying over it. Then he says:  

“Well, den, I reck’n I did dream it, Huck; but dog my cats ef it ain’t de powerfulest dream I ever see. En I hain’t ever had no dream b’fo’ dat’s tired me like dis one.”  

“Oh, well, that’s all right, because a dream does tire a body like everything sometimes. But this one was a staving dream; tell me all about it, Jim.”  

So Jim went to work and told me the whole thing right through, just as it happened, only he painted it up considerable. Then he said he must start in and “’terpret” it, because it was sent for a warning. He said the first towhead stood for a man that would try to do us some good, but the current was another man that would get us away from him. The whoops was warnings that would come to us every now and then, and if we didn’t try hard to make out to understand them they’d just take us into bad luck, ’stead of keeping us out of it. The lot of towheads was troubles we was going to get into with quarrelsome people and all kinds of mean folks, but if we minded our business and didn’t talk back and aggravate them, we would pull through and get out of the fog and into the big clear river, which was the free States, and wouldn’t have no more trouble.  

It had clouded up pretty dark just after I got on to the raft, but it was clearing up again now.  

“Oh, well, that’s all interpreted well enough as far as it goes, Jim,” I says; “but what does these things stand for?”  

It was the leaves and rubbish on the raft and the smashed oar. You could see them first-rate now.  

Jim looked at the trash, and then looked at me, and back at the trash again. He had got the dream fixed so strong in his head that he couldn’t seem to shake it loose and get the facts back into its place again right away. But when he did get the thing straightened around he looked at me steady without ever smiling, and says:  

“What do dey stan’ for? I’s gwyne to tell you. When I got all wore out wid work, en wid de callin’ for you, en went to sleep, my heart wuz mos’ broke bekase you wuz los’, en I didn’ k’yer no’ mo’ what become er me en de raf’. En when I wake up en fine you back ag’in, all safe en soun’, de tears come, en I could a got down on my knees en kiss yo’ foot, I’s so thankful. En all you wuz thinkin’ ’bout wuz how you could make a fool uv ole Jim wid a lie. Dat truck dah is trash; en trash is what people is dat puts dirt on de head er dey fren’s en makes ’em ashamed.”  

Then he got up slow and walked to the wigwam, and went in there without saying anything but that. But that was enough. It made me feel so mean I could almost kissed his foot to get him to take it back.  

It was fifteen minutes before I could work myself up to go and humble myself to a nigger; but I done it, and I warn’t ever sorry for it afterward, neither. I didn’t do him no more mean tricks, and I wouldn’t done that one if I’d a knowed it would make him feel that way.  

---

detailed_summary: At four in the morning, when Jim woke Huck for his watch, Jim expressed a hope that they wouldn't encounter any more kings on their journey.
Jim commented that having one or two kings was sufficient, noting that their current king was often very drunk, and the duke wasn't much better.
Huck then learned that Jim had attempted to persuade the king to speak French, simply because Jim was curious to hear it.
The king, however, had claimed that he had been in America for such a long time and had experienced so many difficulties that he had forgotten how to speak French.

events.title: Theatrical Rehearsals and Mishaps on the Raft
detailed_summary: After sunrise, the King and the Duke, looking worse for wear, were invigorated by a swim in the river.
Following breakfast, the King settled on the raft's edge, dangling his legs in the water, lit his pipe, and began memorizing his lines for Romeo and Juliet.
The Duke and King then rehearsed together, with the Duke meticulously instructing the King on the proper delivery for each of Romeo's speeches.

The Duke stressed that Romeo's words should be spoken softly and with a sense of longing and illness, fitting for addressing Juliet, whom he described as a sweet young girl, not to be addressed with a booming voice.
Subsequently, they practiced a sword fight using long swords fashioned by the Duke from oak laths, with the Duke portraying Richard III, creating an impressive spectacle as they moved about the raft.
The practice session was interrupted when the King stumbled and fell into the river.
After this incident, they ceased their rehearsal, rested, and engaged in conversation about various adventures they had experienced on the river in the past.

It was after sun-up now, but we went right on and didn’t tie up. The king and the duke turned out by-and-by looking pretty rusty; but after they’d jumped overboard and took a swim it chippered them up a good deal. After breakfast the king he took a seat on the corner of the raft, and pulled off his boots and rolled up his britches, and let his legs dangle in the water, so as to be comfortable, and lit his pipe, and went to getting his Romeo and Juliet by heart. When he had got it pretty good, him and the duke begun to practice it together. The duke had to learn him over and over again how to say every speech; and he made him sigh, and put his hand on his heart, and after a while he said he done it pretty well; “only,” he says, “you mustn’t bellow out Romeo! that way, like a bull—you must say it soft and sick and languishy, so—R-o-o-meo! that is the idea; for Juliet’s a dear sweet mere child of a girl, you know, and she doesn’t bray like a jackass.”
Well, next they got out a couple of long swords that the duke made out of oak laths, and begun to practice the sword fight—the duke called himself Richard III.; and the way they laid on and pranced around the raft was grand to see. But by-and-by the king tripped and fell overboard, and after that they took a rest, and had a talk about all kinds of adventures they’d had in other times along the river.

Still, I reckoned we’d made good distance, and as long as we kept moving by night and laying low by day, we stood a chance. Jim said the Ohio was our best hope, and I trusted him.

events.title: Crafting an Encore: The Duke's "Hamlet" and the King's Enthusiasm
detailed_summary: Following their dinner, the Duke expressed a desire to elevate their show to a first-class production, suggesting the addition of more content, particularly something for encores.
The King, unfamiliar with the term "onkores," prompted the Duke to provide an explanation.
The Duke outlined his plan for an encore, intending to perform either the Highland fling or a sailor's hornpipe, and then decided the King should perform Hamlet's soliloquy.
The King was perplexed by the mention of "Hamlet's soliloquy."
The Duke lauded the soliloquy as Shakespeare's most renowned and emotionally powerful piece, asserting it always captivated audiences.

As he didn't have the full text, possessing only one volume of Shakespeare, the Duke endeavored to reconstruct the soliloquy from memory, pacing back and forth with exaggerated expressions of thought and emotion.
He then delivered his pieced-together version with dramatic flair, involving intense gestures and vocalizations, a performance that Huck, the narrator, also learned by heart.
The King was greatly taken with the speech and quickly became proficient in delivering it with impressive vigor and dramatic effect, seemingly a natural fit for the role.

After dinner the duke says:
“Well, Capet, we’ll want to make this a first-class show, you know, so I guess we’ll add a little more to it. We want a little something to answer encores with, anyway.”
“What’s onkores, Bilgewater?”
The duke told him, and then says:

After dinner the duke says, “Well, gentlemen, we’ve got ourselves a fine little setup here, but we ain’t done yet. There’s money to be made, and I reckon we ought to strike while the iron’s hot.”  

The king, lounging back in his chair with a satisfied grin, nods and says, “You’re right about that, Duke. These folks here are ripe for the pluckin’. What’s your scheme?”  

The duke leans forward, his eyes gleaming with mischief. “I been thinkin’ about a show—something grand, something that’ll make ‘em open their purses wide. How about a Shakespearean tragedy? ‘The Royal Nonesuch,’ we’ll call it. Folks in these parts ain’t seen real high-class entertainment, and they’ll pay good money to say they have.”  

Huck, who’s been listening quietly, feels a twist in his gut. He knows the duke and the king are up to no good, but he ain’t sure what to do about it. Jim, sitting off to the side, gives Huck a worried look but don’t say nothing.  

The king slaps his knee and laughs. “That’s a fine idea, Duke! We’ll charge fifty cents a head—no, a dollar! And we’ll make it so mysterious they’ll be beggin’ to see it.”  

The duke nods. “Exactly. We’ll put up posters all over town, sayin’ it’s a performance so grand it can’t be described—only witnessed. That’ll get ‘em curious.”  

Huck can’t help but speak up. “But what if they don’t like it? What if they figure out it’s a swindle?”  

The duke waves a hand. “Oh, they’ll like it just fine. And even if they don’t, by the time they realize, we’ll be long gone with their money.”  

The king chuckles. “That’s the beauty of it, Huck. These rubes won’t know what hit ‘em.”  

Huck don’t like it one bit, but he keeps his mouth shut. He knows arguing with these two is like trying to stop a river with his hands.  

The next day, the duke gets to work painting up fancy posters with big, bold letters:  

**“THE ROYAL NONESUCH!”**  
**A TRAGEDY OF UNPARALLELED GRANDEUR!**  
**ONE NIGHT ONLY! ADMISSION: $1**  
**LADIES AND CHILDREN NOT ADMITTED!**  

The king struts around town, telling folks it’s the most shocking, most thrilling spectacle ever to grace the stage. By evening, the whole town’s buzzing with excitement.  

That night, the hall’s packed with men, all eager to see what the fuss is about. The duke steps out in front of the curtain and gives a grand speech about the majesty of Shakespeare, then disappears behind the curtain.  

What follows ain’t no tragedy—it’s a disgrace. The king comes out painted up like a wild man, prancing around buck naked except for some stripes of paint. The crowd gasps, then starts hollerin’ and laughing. It’s pure foolishness, and after about three minutes, the duke pulls the curtain shut.  

The men in the crowd are furious. They’ve been had. But before they can storm the stage, the duke steps out again, grinning like a possum.  

“Gentlemen!” he cries. “You have just witnessed the most daring performance ever conceived! The Royal Nonesuch is meant to be seen only once—its power is too great for a second viewing! Tell your friends, but beware—none can endure its glory twice!”  

Some of the men grumble, but others, not wanting to admit they’ve been fooled, start clapping. The duke and the king bow, then slip out the back before anyone can demand their money back.

events.title: Scouting and Advertising the Show in an Arkansas Town
detailed_summary: At their earliest convenience, the Duke arranged for the printing of show bills.
For the subsequent two or three days, as they drifted downriver, the raft was exceptionally animated with continuous sword-fighting and theatrical rehearsals.
While navigating through Arkansas, they came upon a small, unremarkable town located in a prominent bend of the river.

They secured their raft approximately three-quarters of a mile upstream, concealed within a cypress-bordered creek, and everyone except Jim disembarked in a canoe to explore the town's prospects for their performance.
They discovered that a circus was scheduled for that afternoon, with rural attendees already arriving, but its departure by nightfall would create an opportunity for their show.
The Duke successfully rented the local courthouse as their venue, and the group then proceeded to distribute their promotional posters throughout the town.

The show bills ambitiously proclaimed a "Shaksperean Revival!!!" as a "Wonderful Attraction! For One Night Only!" featuring the "world renowned tragedians, David Garrick the younger" (the Duke) and "Edmund Kean the elder" (the King), from prestigious London theatres, performing "The Balcony Scene" from Romeo and Juliet, a "thrilling, masterly, and blood-curdling Broad-sword conflict In Richard III.!!!", and, by special request, "Hamlet’s Immortal Soliloquy!!" by Kean, allegedly performed for 300 consecutive nights in Paris, all due to "imperative European engagements." Admission was priced at 25 cents, with a reduced rate of 10 cents for children and servants.

The first chance we got, the duke he had some show bills printed; and after that, for two or three days as we floated along, the raft was a most uncommon lively place, for there warn’t nothing but sword-fighting and rehearsing—as the duke called it—going on all the time.  

The duke and the dauphin—though I reckon neither one was any more royal than a mudcat—took to strutting about like they owned creation. The duke, he’d wave his arms and holler out his lines like he was addressing a crowd of thousands, while the dauphin pranced around with a stick for a sword, pretending to duel invisible foes. They’d argue over how the play ought to go, each one thinking his own way was the grandest.  

Jim and I mostly kept out of their way, watching from the sidelines. Jim would shake his head and mutter, “Dem two ain’t right in de head,” and I couldn’t help but agree. Still, there was something mighty entertaining about seeing two grown men carrying on like children, especially when they’d trip over each other or forget their lines and start cussing.  

The duke had big plans, though. He said we’d stop at the next town and put on a performance that’d have folks lining up to hand over their money. I didn’t have much faith in their acting, but I reckoned if they could fool folks into thinking they were royalty, they might just fool ‘em into paying for a show.  

All the same, I couldn’t shake the feeling that trouble was brewing. Those two were bound to stir up something, and when they did, Jim and I would have to be ready to light out quick.

events.title: Huck's Observations of a Dilapidated Arkansas Town and its Idle Inhabitants
characters: Loafers (Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, Andy, Lafe Buckner)
detailed_summary: The group then wandered through the town, taking in its general state of disrepair.

Huck noted that the stores and houses were predominantly old, unpainted wooden structures, elevated on stilts to protect against river flooding. Their gardens appeared neglected, primarily cultivating weeds, sunflowers, and accumulating debris like ash-piles and old discarded items.

The fences were haphazardly constructed from various types of boards added at different times, leaning in multiple directions, and often equipped with only a single leather hinge for a gate. Some bore faint remnants of whitewash, which the Duke humorously suggested dated back to Columbus's era.
Hogs were a common sight in gardens, with residents frequently attempting to shoo them away.
All the town's stores were situated along a single street, featuring white fabric awnings in front, where country visitors would tie their horses.

Under these awnings, idle men, referred to as loafers, spent their days perched on empty dry-goods boxes, whittling wood with Barlow knives, chewing tobacco, and exhibiting general lethargy through yawning and stretching—a rather uncouth assembly.

These men typically wore wide-brimmed yellow straw hats but no coats or waistcoats, addressed each other by familiar names like Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, and Andy, spoke in a slow, lazy drawl, and used a considerable amount of profanity.
Nearly every awning-post had a loafer leaning against it, usually with hands in pockets, except when retrieving tobacco or scratching.
Huck described their conversations, highlighting the frequent requests to borrow chewing tobacco, often accompanied by false claims about having just given away their last piece.
He detailed the ritual of sharing tobacco, where a borrower would gnaw off a piece from a plug, sometimes to the feigned dismay of the owner.
The town's streets and alleys were entirely composed of mud, deep and black in places, and universally present.

Hogs were ubiquitous, lounging and grunting throughout the town. A common sight was a muddy sow with her piglets leisurely occupying a walkway, forcing people to detour, while she appeared contentedly nursing her young.

This tranquility would often be broken by a loafer inciting a dog to chase the sow, leading to a chaotic pursuit that amused the onlookers, who would then resettle until the next diversion, such as a dog fight.
The narrator observed that nothing animated the loafers as much as a dog fight, unless it was a cruel prank like setting fire to a stray dog or tying a tin pan to its tail.
Some houses along the riverfront were precariously situated, leaning and appearing ready to collapse into the water due to erosion, though some were still inhabited despite the danger.
The town was in a constant state of retreat as the river relentlessly eroded its banks.

events.text_segment:
Then we went loafing around the town. The stores and houses was most all old shackly dried-up frame concerns that hadn’t ever been painted; they was set up three or four foot above ground on stilts, so as to be out of reach of the water when the river was overflowed. The houses had little gardens around them, but they didn’t seem to raise hardly anything in them but jimpson weeds, and sunflowers, and ash-piles, and old curled-up boots and shoes, and pieces of bottles, and rags, and played-out tin-ware. The fences was made of different kinds of boards, nailed on at different times; and they leaned every which-way, and had gates that didn’t generly have but one hinge—a leather one. Some of the fences had been whitewashed, some time or another, but the duke said it was in Clumbus’s time, like enough. There was generly hogs in the garden, and people driving them out.
All the stores was along one street. They had white domestic awnings in front, and the country people hitched their horses to the awning-posts. There was empty drygoods boxes under the awnings, and loafers roosting on them all day long, whittling them with their Barlow knives; and chawing tobacco, and gaping and yawning and stretching—a mighty ornery lot. They generly had on yellow straw hats most as wide as an umbrella, but didn’t wear no coats nor waistcoats, they called one another Bill, and Buck, and Hank, and Joe, and Andy, and talked lazy and drawly, and used considerable many cuss words. There was as many as one loafer leaning up against every awning-post, and he most always had his hands in his britches-pockets, except when he fetched them out to lend a chaw of tobacco or scratch. What a body was hearing amongst them all the time was:
“Gimme a chaw ’v tobacker, Hank.”
“Cain’t; I hain’t got but one chaw left. Ask Bill.”
Maybe Bill he gives him a chaw; maybe he lies and says he ain’t got none. Some of them kinds of loafers never has a cent in the world, nor a chaw of tobacco of their own. They get all their chawing by borrowing; they say to a fellow, “I wisht you’d len’ me a chaw, Jack, I jist this minute give Ben Thompson the last chaw I had”—which is a lie pretty much everytime; it don’t fool nobody but a stranger; but Jack ain’t no stranger, so he says:
“You give him a chaw, did you? So did your sister’s cat’s grandmother. You pay me back the chaws you’ve awready borry’d off’n me, Lafe Buckner, then I’ll loan you one or two ton of it, and won’t charge you no back intrust, nuther.”
“Well, I did pay you back some of it wunst.”
“Yes, you did—’bout six chaws. You borry’d store tobacker and paid back nigger-head.”
Store tobacco is flat black plug, but these fellows mostly chaws the natural leaf twisted. The streets were dusty, and the sun beat down something fierce, but we didn’t mind much. He gave us a squinty-eyed look, like he was trying to decide whether we were up to no good, but Huck just tipped his hat and said, "Afternoon, Mr. Higgins," real polite-like. That seemed to satisfy him, and he went back to his whittling without another word.

Further down, we came across a group of boys playing marbles in the shade of the blacksmith’s shop. They were whooping and hollering, and one little fellow was hopping around like he’d just won a fortune. Huck nudged me and whispered, "Bet you a nickel I can beat the lot of ’em." I knew better than to take that bet—Huck had a knack for marbles, and he’d cleaned me out more than once back home. 

We watched for a spell, and sure enough, Huck sauntered over and joined in. Inside of ten minutes, he’d won every last marble from those boys, fair and square. They looked mighty put out about it, but Huck just grinned and handed ’em all back. "Keep ’em," he said. "I was just funnin’ with ya." That set ’em all to laughing, and before long, we were all friends, swapping stories and carrying on like we’d known each other forever.

After a while, we moseyed on down to the riverbank, where the water was slow and lazy under the afternoon sun. Huck picked up a flat stone and skipped it across the surface—one, two, three, four jumps before it sank. "Beat that," he challenged, and I tried my best, but my stone only managed two hops before disappearing with a plunk. Huck laughed and clapped me on the back. "You’ll get the hang of it," he said, though I had my doubts.

We sat there for a spell, watching the river roll by and listening to the distant sound of a steamboat whistle. Huck got that far-off look in his eyes, the one he always got when he was thinking about lighting out for the territories. "Ain’t it something," he said, "how a feller could just get on a raft and go wherever the current takes him? No rules, no bosses, just the wide open river and whatever lies beyond."

I nodded, knowing exactly what he meant. There was something mighty tempting about the idea of leaving all your troubles behind and setting off into the unknown. But then my stomach growled something fierce, reminding me that adventures were best undertaken on a full belly. "Reckon we ought to find some supper," I said, and Huck agreed.

We headed back into town, where the smell of frying chicken led us to a little eatery near the square. The place was run by a stout woman with a red face and a no-nonsense manner. She took one look at us and said, "You boys got money to pay for that grub?" Huck patted his pockets like he was checking, but I knew neither of us had a cent to our names. 

Just then, a man at the counter—a traveling salesman by the look of his fancy suit—spoke up. "I’ll cover their meal, ma’am," he said, tipping his hat. "Every boy ought to have a good supper now and then." The woman huffed but dished up two plates heaping with chicken, biscuits, and gravy. We thanked the man kindly and dug in like we hadn’t eaten in a week.

As we ate, the salesman struck up a conversation, telling us tall tales about his travels and the wonders he’d seen. Huck listened with wide eyes, hanging on every word, while I tried to figure out how much of it was true and how much was just wind. Still, it made for fine entertainment, and before we knew it, the sun was starting to dip low in the sky.

We thanked the man again and stepped back out into the cooling evening air. The town was quieter now, with folks heading home for the night. Lanterns glowed in windows, and the sound of a fiddle drifted from somewhere down the street. 

Huck stretched and yawned. "Reckon we ought to find a place to bed down," he said. I agreed, though neither of us had any notion of where that might be. But that was the way of things with Huck—tomorrow was always another day, and somehow, things had a way of working out. 

So we wandered off toward the edge of town, where the trees grew thick and the fireflies were just starting to flicker in the gathering dark. And as we walked, I couldn’t help but feel that no matter where we ended up, as long as I was with Huck Finn, it was bound to be an adventure.

events.title: The Arrival of Drunken Boggs and His Threats Against Colonel Sherburn
detailed_summary: As midday approached, the town's streets became increasingly congested with wagons and horses, with a continuous influx of people.
Families arriving from the countryside ate their meals in their wagons, while considerable whisky consumption and at least three fights were observed by Huck.
Suddenly, someone announced the arrival of "old Boggs" from the country for his regular monthly drunken spree.

The loafers appeared pleased, evidently accustomed to deriving entertainment from Boggs's behavior. One remarked on Boggs's history of unfulfilled threats, while another joked that being threatened by Boggs was a guarantee of a long life.
Boggs then came riding wildly on his horse, shouting like a Native American and proclaiming that he was on the warpath and the price of coffins was about to rise.

He was clearly intoxicated, swaying in his saddle, over fifty years old, with a notably red face. The crowd shouted at him, laughed, and taunted him, and he responded in kind, stating he would deal with them later but first had to kill Colonel Sherburn, adhering to his motto of "Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on."
Boggs noticed Huck, rode up to him, and asked if he was prepared to die, before continuing on his way.

Huck was frightened by the encounter, but a bystander reassured him that Boggs meant no harm, describing him as a habitually boisterous but ultimately harmless drunkard, the most good-natured old fool in Arkansas, who never injured anyone, whether drunk or sober.

events.text_segment:
The nearer it got to noon that day the thicker and thicker was the wagons and horses in the streets, and more coming all the time. Families fetched their dinners with them from the country, and eat them in the wagons. There was considerable whisky drinking going on, and I seen three fights. By-and-by somebody sings out:
“Here comes old Boggs!—in from the country for his little old monthly drunk; here he comes, boys!”
All the loafers looked glad; I reckoned they was used to having fun out of Boggs. One of them says:
“Wonder who he’s a-gwyne to chaw up this time. If he’d a-chawed up all the men he’s ben a-gwyne to chaw up in the last twenty year he’d have considerable ruputation now.”
Another one says, “I wisht old Boggs ’d threaten me, ’cuz then I’d know I warn’t gwyne to die for a thousan’ year.”
Boggs comes a-tearing along on his horse, whooping and yelling like an Injun, and singing out:
“Cler the track, thar. I’m on the waw-path, and the price uv coffins is a-gwyne to raise.”
He was drunk, and weaving about in his saddle; he was over fifty year old, and had a very red face. Everybody yelled at him and laughed at him and sassed him, and he sassed back, and said he’d attend to them and lay them out in their regular turns, but he couldn’t wait now because he’d come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was, “Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on.”
He see me, and rode up and says:
“Whar’d you come f’m, boy? You prepared to die?”
Then he rode on. I was scared, but a man says:
“He don’t mean nothing; he’s always a-carryin’ on like that when he’s drunk. He’s the best naturedest old fool in Arkansaw—never hurt nobody, drunk nor sober.”

events.title: Colonel Sherburn's Ultimatum and Boggs's Continued Defiance
detailed_summary: Boggs positioned himself in front of the town's most prominent store and, peering under the awning, loudly called for Sherburn to come out and face him, accusing Sherburn of swindling him and declaring his intent to get him.
He continued to hurl every insult he could think of at Sherburn, while the street filled with people who listened, laughed, and commented on the spectacle.
After some time, a distinguished-looking man of about fifty-five, who was also the best-dressed individual in town, stepped out of the store. The crowd instinctively fell back to allow him passage.

This man, Colonel Sherburn, addressed Boggs in a very calm and deliberate manner, stating that he was tired of Boggs's behavior but would tolerate it until one o'clock, and no later. He warned Boggs that if he uttered even one more word against him after that time, Sherburn would find him, no matter how far he traveled.
Sherburn then turned and went back into the store. The crowd became very subdued; no one moved, and the laughter ceased.

Boggs, however, rode off, continuing to revile Sherburn as loudly as he could yell, all the way down the street. Shortly after, he returned and stopped before the store, resuming his abusive shouting.
Some men gathered around Boggs, attempting to persuade him to be quiet, and told him it would be one o'clock in about fifteen minutes, urging him to go home immediately. Their efforts were futile.
Boggs persisted in his cursing with all his might, threw his hat into the mud, rode his horse over it, and then galloped off down the street again in a rage, his gray hair flying.
Everyone who could get near him tried to coax him off his horse so they could detain him and let him sober up, but to no avail—he would tear up the street again to hurl more curses at Sherburn.
Eventually, someone suggested fetching Boggs's daughter, reasoning that she sometimes had influence over him and might be able to persuade him if anyone could.
Following this suggestion, someone set off running to find her.

Boggs rode up before the biggest store in town, and bent his head down so he could see under the curtain of the awning and yells:
“Come out here, Sherburn! Come out and meet the man you’ve swindled. You’re the houn’ I’m after, and I’m a-gwyne to have you, too!”
And so he went on, calling Sherburn everything he could lay his tongue to, and the whole street packed with people listening and laughing and going on. By-and-by a proud-looking man about fifty-five—and he was a heap the best dressed man in that town, too—steps out of the store, and the crowd drops back on each side to let him come. He says to Boggs, mighty ca’m and slow—he says:
“I’m tired of this, but I’ll endure it till one o’clock. Till one o’clock, mind—no longer. If you open your mouth against me only once after that time you can’t travel so far but I will find you.”
Then he turns and goes in. The crowd looked mighty sober; nobody stirred, and there warn’t no more laughing. Boggs rode off blackguarding Sherburn as loud as he could yell, all down the street; and pretty soon back he comes and stops before the store, still keeping it up. Some men crowded around him and tried to get him to shut up, but he wouldn’t; they told him it would be one o’clock in about fifteen minutes, and so he must go home—he must go right away. But it didn’t do no good. He cussed away with all his might, and throwed his hat down in the mud and rode over it, and pretty soon away he went a-raging down the street again, with his gray hair a-flying. Everybody that could get a chance at him tried their best to coax him off of his horse so they could lock him up and get him sober; but it warn’t no use—up the street he would tear again, and give Sherburn another cussing. By-and-by somebody says:
“Go for his daughter!—quick, go for his daughter; sometimes he’ll listen to her. If anybody can persuade him, she can.”
So somebody started on a run.

"Come out here, Sherburn! Come out and face me like a man, you yeller coward!" His voice was rough and full of anger, and folks on the street stopped what they were doing to watch. Boggs swayed a little in his saddle, his face red from drink, but his eyes burned with a wild, reckless fire.

Then, real quiet but sharp as a knife, Sherburn said, "I give you till one o’clock to leave town, Boggs. One o’clock. After that, I won’t be responsible for what happens."  

Boggs’ face twisted. He opened his mouth like he wanted to say something else, but no words came. His horse shifted under him, sensing the tension. The whole street was dead silent, waiting.

events.title: Colonel Sherburn Shoots Boggs in Cold Blood
detailed_summary: Huck, having moved further down the street, paused and observed Boggs being hurried along by two companions, one on each arm. Boggs was bare-headed, walking unsteadily but not resisting, looking uneasy and actively participating in the hurried movement.
Suddenly, Colonel Sherburn's voice called out, "Boggs!"
Huck looked and saw Colonel Sherburn standing perfectly still in the street, holding a pistol in his right hand, its barrel pointed skyward, not yet aimed.
At that same instant, Huck saw a young girl, Boggs's daughter, running towards them, accompanied by two men.
Boggs and his companions turned to see who had called his name. Upon seeing Sherburn with the pistol, Boggs's escorts jumped to the side.
Sherburn slowly and deliberately lowered the pistol to a level aim, with both barrels cocked.
Boggs threw up both his hands and cried out, "O Lord, don’t shoot!"
The first shot rang out, and Boggs staggered backward, clawing at the air. The second shot followed immediately, and Boggs fell heavily to the ground, his arms spread wide.
The young girl screamed, rushed forward, and threw herself onto her father, crying out that he had been killed.
The crowd quickly closed in around them, jostling and craning their necks to see, while those on the inside tried to push them back, shouting for them to give Boggs air.
Colonel Sherburn casually tossed his pistol onto the ground, turned on his heel, and walked away.

events.title: Boggs's Death, the Town's Morbid Curiosity, and the Call for Lynching Sherburn
detailed_summary: Boggs was transported to a small drugstore, with the crowd maintaining its tight formation around him and the entire town trailing behind. Huck managed to secure a prime viewing spot at the window, close enough to see everything inside.

Inside the drugstore, Boggs was laid on the floor. A large Bible was placed under his head, and another was opened and spread across his chest, but only after his shirt was torn open, revealing to Huck the entry point of one of the bullets.
Boggs took about a dozen deep, gasping breaths, his chest rising and falling with the Bible, before he became still; he was dead.

His daughter, screaming and crying, was then pulled away from his body and taken off. She was described as about sixteen years old, with a sweet and gentle appearance, though terribly pale and frightened.

Soon, the entire town seemed to have gathered, squirming and pushing to get to the window for a look, while those already occupying the vantage points refused to yield them. People in the back complained about the unfairness of others monopolizing the view.
Amidst considerable bickering, Huck decided to leave, anticipating potential trouble.
The streets were packed with excited people. Everyone who had witnessed the shooting was recounting the details, surrounded by large, attentive crowds craning their necks to listen.

One particularly notable figure, a tall, lanky man with long hair, a large white fur stovepipe hat worn on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, demonstrated the sequence of events. He marked the spots on the ground where Boggs and Sherburn had stood, and the crowd followed him from place to place, observing his every move, nodding to show their understanding, and stooping to watch him mark the locations with his cane.

This man then stood straight and stiff where Sherburn had been, frowning with his hat brim pulled low over his eyes, shouted "Boggs!", then slowly brought his cane down to a level as if aiming, said "Bang!", staggered backward, said "Bang!" again, and fell flat on his back.
Those who had seen the actual shooting declared his reenactment perfect, stating it was exactly how it had all occurred. Afterward, as many as a dozen people offered him drinks from their bottles.
After a while, someone suggested that Colonel Sherburn should be lynched.
Within about a minute, this sentiment was echoed by everyone, and the crowd, now enraged and shouting, set off, tearing down every clothesline they encountered to use for the hanging.

They took Boggs to a little drug store, the crowd pressing around just the same, and the whole town following, and I rushed and got a good place at the window, where I was close to him and could see in. They laid him on the floor and put one large Bible under his head, and opened another one and spread it on his breast; but they tore open his shirt first, and I seen where one of the bullets went in. He made about a dozen long gasps, his breast lifting the Bible up when he drawed in his breath, and letting it down again when he breathed it out—and after that he laid still; he was dead. Then they pulled his daughter away from him, screaming and crying, and took her off. She was about sixteen, and very sweet and gentle-looking, but awful pale and scared.
Well, pretty soon the whole town was there, squirming and scrouging and pushing and shoving to get at the window and have a look, but people that had the places wouldn’t give them up, and folks behind them was saying all the time, “Say, now, you’ve looked enough, you fellows; ’tain’t right and ’tain’t fair for you to stay thar all the time, and never give nobody a chance; other folks has their rights as well as you.”
There was considerable jawing back, so I slid out, thinking maybe there was going to be trouble. The streets was full, and everybody was excited. Everybody that seen the shooting was telling how it happened, and there was a big crowd packed around each one of these fellows, stretching their necks and listening. One long, lanky man, with long hair and a big white fur stovepipe hat on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, marked out the places on the ground where Boggs stood and where Sherburn stood, and the people following him around from one place to t’other and watching everything he done, and bobbing their heads to show they understood, and stooping a little and resting their hands on their thighs to watch him mark the places on the ground with his cane; and then he stood up straight and stiff where Sherburn had stood, frowning and having his hat-brim down over his eyes, and sung out, “Boggs!” and then fetched his cane down slow to a level, and says “Bang!” staggered backwards, says “Bang!” again, and fell down flat on his back. The people that had seen the thing said he done it perfect; said it was just exactly the way it all happened. Then as much as a dozen people got out their bottles and treated him.
Well, by-and-by somebody said Sherburn ought to be lynched. In about a minute everybody was saying it; so away they went, mad and yelling, and snatching down every clothes-line they come to, to do the hanging with.

events.title: Sherburn's Scathing Rebuke of the Mob's Cowardice
detailed_summary: Sherburn remained silent, his steady gaze sweeping across the crowd, making individuals uncomfortable and avoid eye contact.
He then gave a scornful laugh before addressing them.
He mocked their presumption to lynch anyone, especially a man, contrasting it with their bravery in tarring and feathering vulnerable women.
Sherburn asserted that a true man would be safe from thousands of their kind in daylight, as long as he wasn't attacked from behind.
He claimed a thorough understanding of their character, based on his experiences in both the South and North, concluding that the average person is a coward.

He elaborated on regional cowardice: Northerners passively endure mistreatment, while Southerners commit acts like stagecoach robberies or form lynch mobs for jury-acquitted murderers due to fear of reprisal.
He chided the mob for not adhering to the 'proper' method of lynching—at night, masked, and led by a 'man'—identifying Buck Harkness as merely 'part of a man' who initiated their current folly.
He accused them of lacking genuine desire for confrontation, stating they joined out of fear of being exposed as cowards if they didn't follow an instigator like Harkness.
He described a mob as pitiful, its courage borrowed from the group and its leaders, and a mob without a true leader as even more contemptible.
He ordered them to leave with their 'half-a-man,' emphasizing that any genuine lynching would be done in the dark, Southern style, with masks and a proper leader, while cocking his gun.

events.text_segment:
Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. The stillness was awful creepy and uncomfortable. Sherburn run his eye slow along the crowd; and wherever it struck the people tried a little to out-gaze him, but they couldn’t; they dropped their eyes and looked sneaky. Then pretty soon Sherburn sort of laughed; not the pleasant kind, but the kind that makes you feel like when you are eating bread that’s got sand in it.
Then he says, slow and scornful:
“The idea of you lynching anybody! It’s amusing. The idea of you thinking you had pluck enough to lynch a man! Because you’re brave enough to tar and feather poor friendless cast-out women that come along here, did that make you think you had grit enough to lay your hands on a man? Why, a man’s safe in the hands of ten thousand of your kind—as long as it’s daytime and you’re not behind him.
“Do I know you? I know you clear through. I was born and raised in the South, and I’ve lived in the North; so I know the average all around. The average man’s a coward. In the North he lets anybody walk over him that wants to, and goes home and prays for a humble spirit to bear it. In the South one man all by himself, has stopped a stage full of men in the daytime, and robbed the lot. Your newspapers call you a brave people so much that you think you are braver than any other people—whereas you’re just as brave, and no braver. Why don’t your juries hang murderers? Because they’re afraid the man’s friends will shoot them in the back, in the dark—and it’s just what they would do.
“So they always acquit; and then a man goes in the night, with a hundred masked cowards at his back and lynches the rascal. Your mistake is, that you didn’t bring a man with you; that’s one mistake, and the other is that you didn’t come in the dark and fetch your masks. You brought part of a man—Buck Harkness, there—and if you hadn’t had him to start you, you’d a taken it out in blowing.
“You didn’t want to come. The average man don’t like trouble and danger. You don’t like trouble and danger. But if only half a man—like Buck Harkness, there—shouts ‘Lynch him! lynch him!’ you’re afraid to back down—afraid you’ll be found out to be what you are—cowards—and so you raise a yell, and hang yourselves on to that half-a-man’s coat-tail, and come raging up here, swearing what big things you’re going to do. The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that’s what an army is—a mob; they don’t fight with courage that’s born in them, but with courage that’s borrowed from their mass, and from their officers. But a mob without any man at the head of it is beneath pitifulness. Now the thing for you to do is to droop your tails and go home and crawl in a hole. If any real lynching’s going to be done, it will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they’ll bring their masks, and fetch a man along. Now leave—and take your half-a-man with you”—tossing his gun up across his left arm and cocking it when he says this.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. The crowd had gathered in front of his house, shouting and cursing, calling for his blood. They were a rough bunch, drunk on whiskey and anger, their faces twisted with rage. But Sherburn didn’t flinch. He just stood on his porch, cool as a cucumber, his eyes steady and his hands loose at his sides.  

I was hiding behind a barrel, peeking out, my heart pounding like a drum. I’d never seen a mob like this before, and I sure didn’t want to get caught up in it. But I couldn’t look away neither. There was something about Sherburn—something that made you feel like he knew something the rest of us didn’t.  

Then, real slow, he raised his head and looked at the crowd. His voice wasn’t loud, but it cut through the noise like a knife.  

“You call yourselves men?” he said. “Look at you—a pack of cowards, hiding behind each other, too scared to face me alone.”  

The crowd muttered and shifted, but nobody stepped forward. Sherburn’s lip curled in a sneer.  

“I know your kind,” he went on. “You’re brave when it’s ten against one, when you’ve got the law on your side—or when you think you do. But the truth is, you ain’t got the sand to do what’s right. You follow the loudest voice, the meanest drunk, and you call that justice.”  

A few men in the crowd looked down, shuffling their feet. Others grumbled, but their voices didn’t have the same fire as before.  

Sherburn took a step forward, and the whole mob took a step back. That’s when I knew—they weren’t gonna do a thing. All their bluster was just hot air.  

“Go home,” Sherburn said, quiet-like. “Before you make fools of yourselves.”  

For a second, nobody moved. Then, one by one, they started to drift away, muttering under their breath, but not daring to meet Sherburn’s eye. In less than a minute, the street was empty, save for a few stragglers who slunk off with their tails between their legs.  

Sherburn watched them go, then turned and walked back inside his house like nothing had happened.  

I stayed behind that barrel for a long time, thinking. I’d always figured a mob was the strongest thing there was—that once folks got riled up, there wasn’t nothing could stop ’em. But Sherburn had faced ’em down without so much as lifting a finger. It wasn’t his gun that scared ’em off—it was the way he carried himself, like he knew he was right and they knew it too.  

It made me wonder about a lot of things—about courage, and cowardice, and what it really means to stand up for yourself. Most of all, it made me see that sometimes, the bravest thing a man can do is just stand his ground and let the world see him for what he is.  

And Sherburn? He was the bravest man I ever saw.

events.title: The Mob Disperses and Huck Attends the Circus
detailed_summary: Following Sherburn's command, the crowd rapidly dispersed in various directions.
Buck Harkness followed them, appearing dejected and diminished.
Huck, although he could have stayed, decided against it.
He proceeded to the circus, waited near the back until the watchman passed, and then discreetly entered under the tent.
Huck reasoned that he needed to conserve his money, given his precarious situation away from home and among strangers, stressing the importance of financial prudence.

The male performers were simply clad in undergarments, without shoes or stirrups, riding with ease, while the female performers, adorned in costly, diamond-studded attire, resembled queens.
Huck considered this spectacle incredibly beautiful, unlike anything he had seen before.
The performers then rose to stand on their horses, moving gracefully and fluidly around the ring.
The men appeared tall and ethereal, their heads seeming to glide near the tent's roof, while the women's flowing dresses billowed softly, resembling lovely parasols.
The pace of their performance increased, with all of them dancing on horseback as the horses leaned into the turns, the ring-master directing with his whip and shouts, and the clown making jokes.
Eventually, all performers released their reins; the ladies placed their hands on their hips, and the gentlemen folded their arms, as the horses continued their spirited movements.
One by one, they elegantly leaped off their horses into the ring, made charming bows, and then quickly exited, eliciting wild applause from the audience.

The ring-master couldn’t ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever could think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn’t noway understand. They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn’t listen, and the whole show come to a standstill. So, then, the ring-master he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn’t be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn’t make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse. So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on. The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down. And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t’other one on t’other side, and the people just crazy. It warn’t funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger. But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood! and the horse a-going like a house afire too. He just stood up there, a-sailing around as easy and comfortable as if he warn’t ever drunk in his life—and then he begun to pull off his clothes and sling them. I don’t know; there may be bullier circuses than what that one was, but I never struck them yet. Anyways, it was plenty good enough for me; and wherever I run across it, it can have all of my custom every time.
